did.unittitle: Manchester papers

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract:
The papers contain correspondence, copies of treaties, speeches and credentials, orders, memoranda, reports, newsletters and other papers mostly relating to diplomatic, political and military affairs in western Europe during the War of the Spanish Succession. In addition to documenting Manchester's missions to the republic of Venice and the court of France, the papers provide much detail on shifting relations among the northern powers, the break between France and England following the former's recognition of James III, English concern over Jacobite activities on the Continent, and negotiations with the Low Countries and Savoy.
Major correspondents writing from England on politics and diplomacy include the Earls of Albemarle, Jersey, Shrewsbury and Sunderland, and secretaries James Vernon, Robert Yard, Joseph Addison and Matthew Prior. Other correspondents include the Duke of Marlborough and J. Chetwynd, writing on military matters, and Sir P. Medows, William Blathwayt, James Cresset, Francis Schonenberg, Abraham Stanyan and Alexander Stanhope, addressing affairs in various countries. Manchester's letters to Blathwayt, located in Series II, describe life at the French court and events leading up to the French violation of the Treaty of Ryswick.

langmaterial.language: In English, French, Latin, Italian and Dutch.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Manchester Papers were purchased in 1987 from Sotheby's on Osborn funds.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Manchester Papers are the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Manchester Papers. James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This register reproduces the calendar of the fifteen Manchester albums that appeared in the Appendix to the Eighth Report of the Royal Commission on Historical Manuscripts (1881). No attempt has been made to correct or revise these item-level descriptions. The two letterbooks were not included in the original calendar. These letters have been listed by recipient, place, and date, but summaries have not been provided.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Manchester Papers are a group of over 1,000 letters and other documents concerning the professional and political activities of Charles Montagu, 1st Duke of Manchester. The collection spans the dates 1697-1737, but the bulk of the material dates from between 1698 and 1708, the years of Manchester's embassies to Venice and Paris.
The collection consists of fifteen albums, two letterbooks, and one box of unbound letters. The items in the albums are arranged in a rough chronological order.

Volume 16 contains copies of letters written by Manchester to William Blathwayt and James Vernon during his service as Ambassador to Paris in 1700-01. The letters provide much information on political events, including the proclamation of the duc d'Anjou as King of Spain, the mounting preparations for war, and the break in relations between England and France following Louis XIV's recognition of James III in violation of the Treaty of Ryswick. There are descriptions of "Jacobite intrigues," life at Versailles, and events in the Low Countries.

Volume 17 contains copies of thirty letters written by Manchester in French between January and April of 1702. They are mainly brief business letters or requests for information. The letters in Box 18 consist mainly of business letters by Manchester to William Blathwayt written between 1699 and 1701.

did.unittitle: Albums
R. Yard to the E of M, giving an account of business in the two Houses of Parliament. Five English regiments had arrived in Ireland from Flanders. Those previously there were "to be broke" Whitehall

Instructions given by King William III to Charles, E of M, upon his appointment as Ambassador Extraordinary to the Republic of Venice. (Printed in Cole's Historical and Political Memoirs , p. 1) Kensington

Henry James, of Queen's College, Cambridge, to the E of M, announcing that the senior Esquire Bedell had been sent to the Earl with a Patent for the office of High Steward of the University. Queen's College

The Duke of Shrewsbury to the E of M, giving him notice that he would shortly be despatched on his Embassy, and that there would be no difficulty at the Treasury with respect to money.The Duke had suggested to the King the propriety of allowing a secretary. Whitehall
The Duke of Shrewsbury to the Earl of Manchester, allowing that he would be allowed to have a Secretary of the Embassy, viz. Mr. Stanyan. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 2) Whitehall
The Earl of Portland to the E of M, regretting that the King would not make any promise with respect to the post of Exempt of the Guards, vacant through the death of Mr. Davenant. (In French.) Loo

The Earl of Albemarle to the E of M, announcing that the King would allow a Secretary of the Embassy to Venice, and had given the Duke of Shrewsbury instructions to that effect. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's memoirs, p. 3) Loo
The Duke of Shrewsbury to the E of M, wishing the latter success in his capacity of public minister and "bonnes fortunes" as a young man. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 3) Grafton
Additional instructions to the E of M, as Ambassador Extraordinary to the Republic of Venice. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 3) Whitehall
Further additional instructions. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 4) Whitehall
James Vernon to the E of M, promising to send news in a subsequent letter. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 5) Whitehall
James Vernon to the E of M, giving various small items of news and gossip. Whitehall

The E of M to the Duke of Shrewsbury, thanking the latter for exerting his influence with the King to obtain an appointment for Mr. Meeres, etc. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 5) Cologne
The Earl of Portland to the E of M, regretting that they had not met at the Hague. (In French. A translation printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 5) Whitehall

James Vernon to the E of M, regretting that the Duke of Shrewsbury was compelled to leave town on account of his health, and touching the subject of military organization, etc. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 5. Whitehall

The E of M to the Duke of Shrewsbury, to the effect that neither the Prince of Baden nor the townspeople of Nuremberg were satisfied with the terms of the Peace. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 6) Augsberg
The E of M to Sir Joseph Williamson, announcing arrival at Venice. (Draft) Venice
The E of M to the Lord Chamberlain (the Earl of Sunderland), announcing his arrival at Venice. (Draft) Venice
The E of M to the Duke of Shrewsbury, announcing arrival at Venice, etc. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 7) Venice

The E of M to the Duke of Shrewsbury, stating that the Earl had taken a house, and was about to make his arrival known, in form, to the Republic. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 7) Venice
The Earl of Albemarle to the E of M, expressing a hope that the journey to Venice had been agreeable to the end. (In French) Kensington

Statement of legal questions arising out of the wills of William Godolphin, formerly Ambassador to the Court of Spain, with prayer that the E of M might be authorized to employ his offices at Venice for a solemn hearing of a cause relating to Godolphin's money in the Bank of Venice.
The E of M to the Duke of Shrewsbury, announcing that the Earl had officially notified his arrival at Venice to the Republic. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 7) Venice
The E of M to the Duke of Shrewsbury, relating to the expected mode of official reception of the Earl as Ambassador at Venice. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 8) Venice

James Vernon to the E of M, giving an account of proceedings in Parliament, Lord Sunderland's resignation of his staff (as Lord Chamberlain), the arrival of the Czar of Muscovy, etc. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 9) Whitehall
The Duke of Shrewsbury to the E of M, regretting that he had not answered the Earl's letters. Eyford
The E of M to the Duke of Shrewsbury, stating that he had nothing of great importance to communicate. (Draft) Venice
The E of M to the Earl of Albemarle, expressing good will, and stating that his official reception at Venice had been delayed. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 8) Venice
Edward Griffith to the E of M, stating that he wrote by desire of the Prince and Princess (of Denmark) to make excuse for their delay in writing. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p.10) London

The E of M to the Duke of Shrewsbury, complaining of his reception having been needlessly delayed, stating that the day for it had at length been fixed, and giving some details of the political situation. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 9) Venice

R. Yard to the E of M, chiefly upon the subject of the well- known accusation against Mr. Duncombe with respect to Exchequer bills. (This letter is printed in part in Cole's Memoirs, but the most important passage, that relating to Mr. Duncombe, is omitted.) Whitehall
The E of M to the Duke of Shrewsbury, stating that the official reception at Venice had again been postponed, etc. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p.10) Venice

James Vernon to the E of M, announcing the King's opinion that the Earl's stay at Venice need not continue long after the ceremony of reception, and that he doubted the expediency of establishing a Resident there. (Printed. Cole's memoirs, p. 11) Whitehall
The E of M to the Duke of Shrewsbury, giving a brief account of the reception and audience at Venice. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 11) Venice
The Duke of Shrewsbury to the E of M, announcing that the King was not yet disposed to sanction a visit of the Earl to the court of Turin. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 16) Eyford

The E of M to the Duke of Shrewsbury, stating that he hoped soon to receive the answer of the College, and bring his mission to an end. Lord Pagett had been invited by the Grand Vizier to Adrianople. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p.16) Venice
R. Yard to the E of M, giving particulars of Parliamentary business, and chiefly of Mr. Duncombe's defence in the House of Commons with respect to the affair of the Exchequer bills. Whitehall

Copy of a letter from Senators, etc, of thirteen Swiss Cantons to the King of France, expressing gratitude for the regard shown to their interests by him in including them in the terms of the Peace. (In Latin.) Zurich

James Vernon to the Earl of Manchester, announcing that the account of the Earl's audience had been laid before the King, who left it to the Earl to return when he thought proper. (Printed. Cole's Memoir's, p. 16) Whitehall

The E of M to the Duke of Shrewsbury, reporting the progress of his mission, and suggesting the expediency of appointing a Resident at Venice. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 17) Venice
R. Yard to the E of M, giving an account of an unsuccessful attack, in the House of Commons, upon the Lords of the Treasury, on the subject of Exchequer bills, etc. Whitehall

The E of M to the Duke of Shrewsbury, to the effect that he had presented letters from the Prince and Princess of Denmark to the Republic, and that he hoped his mission would be followed by results beneficial to trade. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 21) Venice

Lord Somers to the E of M, congratulating the latter upon the honours received in his Embassy, and complaining of bitter attacks on their party in the House of Commons. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 22) London

R. Yard to the E of M, giving an account of progress of "Mr. Duncombe's Bill" (of Pains and Penalties). Lord Durseley had been appointed Ambassador to Turkey upon the death of Sir James Rushout. Whitehall
The E of M to the Duke of Shrewsbury, expressing his intention of leaving Venice in about ten days. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 23) Venice
The E of M to Mr. Secretary Vernon, to the same effect. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 23) Venice

The E of M to the Duke of Shrewsbury, expressing hopes of a satisfactory reply from the Republic before his departure, and mentioning various reports in reference to foreign politics. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 24) Venice

R. Yard to the E of M, giving an account of the rejection of "Mr. Duncombe's Bill" by the Lords, and mentioning the arrival of Lord Paget with news from Turkey. The Duke of Shrewsbury suffered from spitting of blood. Whitehall

The E of M to the Duke of Shrewsbury, expressing fears that he would not have received as definite an answer as he might be desired from the Republic before leaving Venice. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 24) Venice
The Earl of Portland to the E of M, expressing a hope that the latter had enjoyed himself, especially during the carnival. (In French) Paris

The E of M to the Duke of Shrewsbury, announcing that he had had his audience of leave, was detained in Venice by his brother's illness, and still hoped his mission might in the end have a good effect. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 24) Venice
The E of M to the Duke of Shrewsbury, regretting further delay in leaving Venice from the same cause. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 27) Venice

R. Yard to the E of M, giving briefly the news of the court and an account of racing at Newmarket. There had been an indirect attempt in the House of Commons to make a precedent for admitting Mr. Duncombe to bail. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii. 41) Newmarket

The E of M to Mr. Yard, announcing his arrival in Paris, and requesting that the King might be asked to place a yacht at his disposal to cross the channel. He contrasts the wealth of the English visitors with the poverty of the French, everywhere to be observed. (Draft.) Paris

The E of M to the Duke of Shrewsbury, asking to have a yacht placed at his disposal, and expressing hopes that the Duke approved of his conduct as Ambassador. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 27) Paris

The E of M to the Duke of Shrewsbury, apologising for not having himself notified to the Duke his departure from Venice, on account of his brother's death, and mentioning prevalent rumors of a new war being imminent. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 27) Lyon

The E of M to the Duke of Shrewsbury, announcing his arrival in London and the King's satisfaction with his proceedings, and recommending Mr. Stanyan as a proper person to be resident Ambassador at Venice. (Draft. Printed, in part only, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 27) London
The Duke of Shrewsbury to the E of M, congratulating the Earl upon his return. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 28) Grafton
The Duke of Shrewsbury to the E of M, informing the Earl that the King was not disposed to appoint a Resident at Venice. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 28) Grafton
Speech of the E of M to the Dogeressa of Venice, containing many compliments to herself and the Doge, upon taking leave. (In Italian)
Copy of the credentials given by William III to the E of M for presentation to the Doge of Venice, upon the appointment of the Earl as Ambassador Extraordinary. (In Latin) Kensington

Copy of a letter from King William III to a person unnamed (but who, from internal evidence, must have been Lord Somers, the Lord Chancellor), requesting him to send secretly "the full powers under the Great Seal with the names in blank to treat with C Tall." (i.e. Count Tallard), concerning the succession of the Kingdom of Spain. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 30, and Tindal's continuation of Rapin, vol. ii, p. 456) Loo

Copy of the answer, without signature, in which the writer (Lord Somers) says that he has "put the Seal to the Commission without expecting the return of the warrant," that "the Commission is wrote by Mr. Secretary, and no other creature has the least knowledge of anything besides the persons already named," viz. "Mr. Mount. (Charles Montagu, Chancellor of the Exchequer), Lord Orford, and the Duke of Shrewsbury." In this answer the advantages and disadvantages of the proposed treaty for the partition of Spain are discussed. (Printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 30, and, with a slight variation, in Tindal's continuation of Rapin, vol. ii p. 458) Turnbridge Wells
The E of M's first speech to the Venetian Senate, expressing hopes of the continuance of friendship between England and Venice. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 11)
The E of M's speech upon delivering letters from the Prince and Princess of Denmark to the Venetian Senate. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p.22)
Answer of the Senate to the above speech. (Italian, with translation at foot. Very brief. The translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 23)

Answer of the Senate to the first speech of the E of M, expressing cordial sentiments towards the King of England and his Ambassador. (In Italian, with translation. The translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 12)

Speech of the E of M upon the occasion of presenting his "First Memorial" at Venice, in which he calls attention to the chief points, viz: Redress for injuries to British subjects, especially seamen; removal of restraints on trade as affecting British subjects; the case of the ships "Mary" and "Samuel and Mary"; and justice to the right heirs of Sir Wm. Godolphin. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 17)
Copy of the First Memorial (to which reference is made above) in full. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 18)

Answer of the Senate to the speech made by the E of M (on presenting his first Memorial), expressing a desire to act in accordance with the wishes of the English Government. (Italian, with translation. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 21)

Speech of the E of M, made at his audience of leave at Venice, in which he expresses disappointment at not having received a satisfactory answer to his Memorial before his departure. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 25)

Answer of the Senate to the Memorial of the E of M, and to his speech at the audience of leave, in which particulars are given of the mode of dealing (past and future) with British merchants, with British subjects in Venetian courts, and British seamen entering the Venetian navy, and promises are given that, after due enquiry, justice shall be done with respect to the specific subjects of complaint. (In Italian)
Translation of the above answer. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 25)
James Cressett to the E of M, giving a few particulars respecting the attitude of the Danes, the Duke of Holstein, and the French ministers in the North. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 91) Hamburg
Signor Girolamo Duodo to the E of M, expressing hopes of the settlement of the claims of the heirs of the late Sir William Godolphin. (In Italian) Venice

The King of Sweden to the King of France, complaining of an infraction of the treaty of Oliva by a Saxon force under the command of one Flemming (a Lieutenant-General of the King of Poland), who had invaded Livonia, and requesting the interference of the King of France in support of his guarantee. (Latin. Copy. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 114)

The King of Sweden to the States General, and to the same effect, mutatis mutandis. (Latin, with translation of all but the formal words of address. The translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 114) Stockholm

Abstract of Treaty between the King of England, the King of France, and the States General of the United Provinces, signed at London the 21st Feb. 1699-1700, and at the Hague 25 March 1700 (being second Treaty for the Partition of Spain). (French, with translation. The translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 113) London and the Hague

A "Memoire touchant les affairs d'Orange," being apparently draft instructions from William III, to his Ambassador at Paris respecting the approaching settlement of matters affecting Orange and Burgundy. (In French) London
Instructions, under the sign manual of William III, to Charles, E of M, upon his appointment as Ambassador Extraordinary to the King of France. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 32) Kensington
Copy of credentials for the E of M, directed by William III to the Duchess of Orleans. (In French) Kensington
Copy of similar credentials directed to the Duchess of Burgundy. (In French) Kensington
Copy of similar credentials directed to the Duke of Burgundy. (In French) Kensington
Copy of similar credentials directed to the Dauphin. (In French) Kensington
Copy of similar credentials directed to the Duke of Orleans. (In French) Kensington
Copy of credentials of the E of M to the King of France, Given by William III, to the Earl in his capacity as Ambassador Extraordinary to the Court of France. (In French) Kensington

Copy of agreement between the Ambassador Exraordinary of the King of Portugal and the Resident of the King of Sweden at the Court of France, respecting the conduct of the ministers of the second rank meeting at foreign courts. (In French) Paris

Acknowledgment by the E of M of the receipt of 1,066 ounces of gilt plate from the Treasurer of H.M. Jewels, for the use of his Lordship's chapel during the period of his embassy. List at foot. (Parchment)

The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, conveying the King's wishes with respect to various memorials for the Prince de Vaudemont, Lady Russell, and others upon which representations were to be made at the Court of France. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p.33) Whitehall

The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, with suggestions respecting the proper mode of dealing with matters relating to Mlle. Malanze, and announcing that the bearer had with him the ratification of the "Treaty for the business of Orange." Whitehall

R. Yard to the E of M, announcing that the Ratification of the Convention relating to the principality of Orange had been sent to the Dutch Ambassador at Paris for exchange on the 18th Aug. The son of Sir G. Norton, under sentence of death for the murder of a dancing master, took opium and died, and his aunt attempted suicide in the same way, but was recovering. Whitehall
William Blathwayt to the E of M, conveying the King's desire that the interest of the Prince of Vaudemont should be supported at the Court of France. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 35) Loo
The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, concerning the proposed exchange of MacDonnell for Pierre Peraut, and the privileges of the Scots in France. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 36) Whitehall

William Blathwayt to the E of M, enclosing papers relating to the attack by a French ship upon an English ship sailing from a foreign port, upon which the Earl was to form a complaint. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 37) Loo

Antonio de Ubilla to Mr. Alexander Stanhope, English Ambassador Extraordinary at Madrid, on the subject of the Spanish succession and the Treaty of Partition, contemplated after transactions at Loo, of which he had heard. (In Spanish. Copy. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p.37)

Alexander Stanhope to the E of M, enclosing copies of papers from Antonio de Ubilla, who is described as "Secretary of the Despacho Universal," and expressing satisfaction that correspondence had been commenced with that office. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 37) Madrid

J. Robinson to the E of M, announcing that Swedish troops had marched into the duchy of Holstein to act against the King of Denmark, and that His Majesty (William III) and the States General were doing their utmost for the preservation of peace. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 40) Stockholm

The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, enclosing papers from the merchants concerned in the Danzig ships taken by Du Bart, and giving instructions to press M. Torcy for reparation, etc. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 41) Whitehall
Copy of the Treaty concerning the principality of Orange, with memorandum of the exchange of ratifications.

The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, giving instructions on various points, enclosing a paper presented to the Lords Justices on the subject of the 12 Protestants taken out of a homeward- bound English ship by a French sloop, and suggesting the expediency of making inquiries respecting the "Scotch having any deputies at St. Germain's." (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 42) Whitehall

William Blathwayt to the E of M, instructing him to congratulate Monsieur and Madame (the Duke and Duchess of Orleans), in the King's name, upon the birth of their grandson, the Prince of Lorraine. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 45) Loo

The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, chiefly upon the subject of the goods in the Danzig ships taken by Du Bart, and said to belong to British subjects, with directions to present another memorial on the matter. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 46) Whitehall
The E of M to M. de Torcy, requesting the latter to procure a private audience for him with the King of France on the following morning. (In French. Copy) Paris

G. Stepney to the E of M, expressing fears that he would be detained in Berlin by the outbreak of hostilities in Holstein, and asking patronage for Mr. Lewis. (Printed, in part, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 46) Loo
William Blathwayt to the E of M, conveying the King's instructions to press for the restoration of Brisac. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 44) Loo

Matthew Prior to the E of M, enclosing a memoir upon the case of one Girard (a minister of Neuchatel whom the King of France was protecting against Madame de Nemours, the lawful sovereign of the place), and instructing the Earl to press the court of France for a decision by competent judges. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 44) Loo

William III to the Elector Palatine, expressing an intention of supporting the Treaty of Ryswick, as affecting the Elector, and announcing that the English Ambassador at Paris had been instructed to call the attention of the King of France to the infractions of it. (Copy. In Latin) Loo

R. Yard to the E of M, enclosing letters from William Beston, Governor of Jamaica, with news that the Scotch had "deserted their settlement at Caledonia, in the country of Darien." (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 48) Whitehall

William Blathwayt to the E of M, enclosing a copy of a letter from the King to the Elector Palatine, and instructing the Earl to use his good offices in the Elector's favour at the court of France. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 49) Dieren
Certificate of baptism (by the name of Jacques), on the 26th June 1644, of a son of Monsieur David de Rodon. (In French) Orange

H. Greg to the E of M, stating that the French Ambassador at Copenhagen denied the receipt of definite instructions to restore to English subjects their goods seized on Danzig ships, and requesting the Earl to insist on having positive orders sent to Mr. Chamilly. (Printed almost entire, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 56, but wrongly dated there, "Oct. 8") Copenhagen

R. Yard to the E of M, respecting the intended apprehension of Mills and Lord Drummond's priest, and the King's intention to direct the Spanish ambassador to leave the kingdom. (Partly in cipher, deciphered. Printed as deciphered, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 57) Whitehall

Message sent by Mr. Secretary Vernon to the Spanish Ambassador (who had caused an offensive paper to be delivered to several of the Lords), notifying that the King required him to leave the country within 18 days, and to remain within his house in the meantime. (In French. Copy. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 59) Whitehall

Paper entitled "Representation aux premieres Seigneurs et Ministres de l'Angleterre," containing severe animadversions on the proposed Treaty relating to the Spanish succession and the Partition of Spain, which had become known to the Spanish King, and against which he had instructed his Ambassador Extraordinary in England to protest in this form. (In French. Copy. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 58)
J. Hill to the E of M, calling attention to the case of the Prince de Vaudemont, and recommending his Highness's Secretary to the Earl's favour. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 60) Brussels

J. Hill to the E of M, giving some particulars of one O'Bryan, a suspected person, requesting further information about him, and conveying instructions to let the French ministers know how seriously the King interested himself on behalf of the Prince de Vaudemont. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 54) Brussels

Hugh Broughton to the E of M, deprecating any efforts to have Count Bosselli released from the Bastille, and giving a number of various items of intelligence. (Printed, in part, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 54) Venice

R. Yard to the E of M, announcing the Spanish Ambassador's speedy departure, and the non-appearance of persons expected at Dover. (Partly in cipher, deciphered. Printed, as deciphered, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 61) Whitehall

The E of M to the Lord Chancellor, expressing regret that Mr. Montague [Montagu] had left the treasury, and anxiety for the speedy conclusion of matters in which the Earl was concerned at Paris. (Draft. Printed, with slight variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 81) Paris

The E of M to Mr. Montague [Montagu], partly upon money matters, and partly giving an account of the difficulties of the Ambassador's position at Paris. (Draft. Printed, with slight variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 82) Paris

Another copy of the "Representation aux premieres Seigneurs Ministres de l'Angleterre" already described, (41), but with the heading "Remonstrance de Dom Pedro Colomna, Ambr. d'Espagne aux Ministres d'Angleterre," and followed by a memorandum of the notice given to the Ambassador to quit England, and of his reply.

R. Yard to the E of M, on the subject apparently of Mills and the other persons expected at Dover. A long letter, almost entirely in cipher, undeciphered. No key to the ciphers of the period is known to exist among the State Papers; but the subject of this document may be inferred from the partial deciphering of previous letters from Yard. Whitehall
Matthew Prior to the E of M, announcing that the King was expected at the Hague, and that O'Bryan had been sent to England, etc. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 61) The Hague
R. Yard to the E of M, on the subject of Mills, Lord Drummond's priest, etc. (Nearly all in cipher, undeciphered) Whitehall
The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, telling him it was the King's wish that he should discuss the Partition Treaty with Mr. Prior. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 66) Whitehall
Extract from letter of Mr. Secretary Vernon to Mr. Cressett upon the mediation in the affairs of Holstein and Denmark. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 69)

The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, upon various subjects connected with the embassy of the latter, with enclosure of extract from Mr. Secretary Vernon's letter to Mr. Cressett upon the subject of Holstein. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 68) Whitehall
The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, upon the conduct of the Ambassador of Portugal at the French Court. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 70) Whitehall
The E of M to Mr. Prior, on the rudeness of the Portuguese Ambassador at Paris, and the Earl's expenses there. (Draft. Printed, with slight variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 64) Paris
Alexander Stanhope to the E of M, giving particulars of the notification he had received to leave Madrid, and enclosing a copy of his answer. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p.71) Madrid
Mr. Stanhope's answer when required to leave the Spanish dominions in 18 days and not to leave his house in the meantime. (Copy. Printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 72)

C. Godolphin to the E of M, requesting him to use his influence with the Venetian Ambassador at Paris and others to procure a just settlement of the claims of the heirs of Sir Wm. Godolphin in respect of money in the Bank of Venice. London

M. de Torcy to the E of M, pointing out a legal difficulty in the case of the Prince de Vaudemont, who, while entering upon his possessions in accordance with the treaty of Ryswick, could enjoy them only subject to previous charges. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 65) Marly

English translation of Mr. Stanhope's notification to Don Antonio de Ubilla that the Spanish Ambassador had been required to leave the domimions of the King of England. Endorsed as having been "delivered at the Escurial the 3d November 1699, n.s." (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 67)

The Duke of Schonburg to the E of M, asking the Earl to make representations to the King of France in order that the Duke might continue in quiet possession of the estates of which the Duke's brother was attempting to dispossess him by law suits. Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 76) London
Alexander Stanhope to the E of M, expressing an opinion that the Spanish Court would probably disavow the recent action of the Spanish Ambassador in London. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 67) Madrid

H. Greg to the E of M, upon the subject of the goods said to belong to British subjects seized on board Danzig ships by the French, with a few remarks on the affairs of Holstein. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 77) Copenhagen
"Mr. Stanhope's Paper to Don Antonio de Ubilla, expressing the King His Majesty's orders to return home, and desiring His Catholic Majesty's passports." (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 72) Madrid

The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, giving directions to employ good offices on behalf of the Prince de Vaudemont, the Prince de Montbeliard, and some French Protestants at the galleys. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 75) Whitehall
Matthew Prior to the E of M, telling of the King's satisfaction with the Earl's proceedings at Paris, and giving various items of gossip. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 76) London

"Copie de la Resolution du Roi du 28 Novembre 1699," being the refusal of the King (of Denmark) to resume the negotiations begun by his father at Pinnenberg with respect to Holstein, on account of the conduct of the Duke of Gottorp. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 78)

Copy of a letter unsigned (written apparently by a spy or conspirator in concealment) directed to "Mr. Proctor, chez M. Veard, à St. Cosme dans la Rue le Harpe, à Paris." It contains little or nothing of importance, but there is at the end this note: "Ld. Middleton's letters come under a cover directed à Mr. Levesque St. Jean, banquier, à Paris."
Matthew Prior to the E of M, on various subjects, and concluding "O'Bryen [O'Bryan] is this morning brought to town." (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 84) Whitehall

The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, on the case of "Count Boscoli," and the "interrogatories of Burk," who was suspected of piracy, etc, in Bretagne. (Printed with the variation of "Bosselli" for "Boscoli," in Cole's Memoirs, p. 84) Whitehall
The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, on points of precedency affecting the ministers at Paris, and mentioning enclosure. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 86) Whitehall
Matthew Prior to the E of M, on business in Parliament and other matters. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 86) Whitehall

M. Hervart to the E of M, to the effect that nothing worthy of note had occurred since the reply of Madame de Nemours to M. de Torcy on the subject of her new Governor, whose displacement had been demanded by the King of France. In a postscript he asks the Earl to give him "une addresse sure," in order that his letters might not be intercepted. (In French) Venice
James Cressett to the E of M, on the probable outbreak of hostilities in Northern Europe. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 85) Hamburg

James Cressett to Mr. Stanyan, expressing hopes that a rupture in the North might be avoided, and mentioning certain points relating to mediation "on the other leaf," which, however, is here wanting. But see 80. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 87) Hamburg
"J. Vanbrook" to the E of M, giving an account of business in Parliament, and various items of gossip. 5 pages. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii. 53) London
Copy of instructions to Mons. de Vrybergh [Vryberge] on the affairs of Neuchâtel and Madame de Nemours. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 90)

The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, enclosing copy of instructions to Mons. de Vrybergh [Vryberge], with whom the E of M is directed to confer on the subject of Neuchâtel. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 90) Hampton Court

Preliminary Articles (five in number) held necessary for the preservation of peace in the North during negotiations. (In Latin. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 87. This is obviously "the other leaf" mentioned in 76.)

Projet de Traité between the King [of France], the Emperor, and the Princes of the Empire, with secret articles relating to subsidies to the Princes from the King, who undertook to make his grandson, the new King of Spain, a party to the treaty. Undated. (In French, p. 8)
Particulars of the representations to be made at the French Court respecting the domains of His Majesty [William III] in France. (In French)

Speeches of the E of M on presenting himself at the French Court, viz., to the Dauphin, to Monsieur, to Madame, to the Duc de Chartres, to the Duchesse de Chartres (unfinished), to the Duc de Bourgogne, to the Duchesse de Bourgogne, and to the Duc d'Anjou et de Berry. (In French)
Another copy of the "Representations aux premieres Seigneurs Ministres de l'Angleterre," as delivered by the Spanish Ambassador Extraordinary in England. (In French.) See 41 and 48.
The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, on "the payment agreed to in relation to Hudson's Bay." (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 92) Whitehall
The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, giving instructions on various subjects. (Partly in cipher. Printed not quite correctly in Cole's Memoirs, p. 94) Whitehall

The Earl of Jersey to the E of M (partly in cipher, deciphered), announcing that "the great affair had come to a good conclusion, the province of Holland having consented." (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 96) Whitehall

The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, giving instructions on the subject of the goods alleged to belong to English subjects, which had been on the Danzig ships taken by the French. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 96) Whitehall
Matthew Prior to the E of M, giving an account of proceedings in Parliament, and of the troublesome and dangerous efforts of the opposition, etc. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 97) Whitehall
James Cressett to the E of M, on the political situation in the North of Europe. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 99) Hamburg.
The Earl of Jersey to the E of M giving instructions on various subjects. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 100) Whitehall
R. Yard to the E of M, giving an account of proceedings in Parliament, etc. Whitehall
The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, giving instructions on various subjects. (Partly in cipher, deciphered. Printed, as deciphered, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 101) Whitehall

The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, on the subject of the Danzig ships, and giving instructions on various matters, and mentioning the approaching signature of the Partition Treaty. (Partly in cipher. Deciphered and printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 102) Whitehall
Matthew Prior to the E of M, on Parliamentary affairs including an expected attack upon the Lord Chancellor. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 103) Whitehall
R. Yard to the E of M, giving a long account of the debates in the House of Commons upon the grants. London

The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, respecting a proposed pardon and pension to some one (described here as la personne, and in other letters as "la personne dont il s'agit") for the discovery of important facts, and giving instructions on other subjects. (Partly in cipher, deciphered. Printed, as deciphered, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 104) Whitehall

Matthew Prior to the E of M, announcing the conclusion of the "grand affair," and mentioning the address of the Commons to the King, "la personne dont il s'agit," etc. (Printed. Cole's memoirs, p. 106) Whitehall

Mr. Lubières to the E of M, requesting the Earl to bring to the notice of M. de Torcy certain difficulties respecting French servants at Orange. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 105) Orange

Copy of Treaty between the Kings of France and Great Britain, and the States General, for the partition of the Spanish dominions after the death of the reigning King of Spain. (In French. p. 12) London
Abstract of the same Treaty as signed at London, 21 February, 1699 (o.s.), and at the Hague, 25 March, 1700 (n.s.) (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 113) London and the Hague
A long and unsigned document on the proposed partition of the Spanish dominions, and its probable consequences. (In Italian. Partly in cipher, deciphered. p. 5)
R. Yard to the E of M, referring to the unpopularity of the King, through his partiality for the Dutch, and giving an account of business in Parliament, including the Bill for the Union. Whitehall
James Cressett to the E of M, on the outbreak of hostilities in Livonia. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 107) Hamburg
Don Silvio Boccone, Cistercian monk, to the E of M ("Duca de M"), asking the Earl to distribute copies of a work written by the monk. (In Italian) Palermo
The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, chiefly on the subject of an alleged plot to murder the King. (Partly in cipher, deciphered. Printed, as deciphered, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 110) Whitehall

The King of Sweden to the King of France, on an infraction of the treaty of Oliva. (Latin. Another copy of the same document has already been described, No. 683, Vol. II of the "Manchester Correspondence," iii.)

The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, on the proceedings of the King of Poland against the Swedes, and announcing that the King of England had fitted out a squadron to preserve the peace. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 111) Whitehall
James Cressett to the E of M, expressing an opinion that affairs in the North depended entirely on the appearance of the English and Dutch flags. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 115) Hamburg
Secret Article of the Second Treaty of Partition. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 119) London and the Hague
R. Yard to the E of M, giving an account of proceedings in Parliament. Whitehall

The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, instructing the latter to represent to the French Court the dangers of war in the North, and touching upon the subjects of the alleged plot, and the Danzig ships. (Partly in cipher, deciphered. Printed, as deciphered, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 117) Whitehall

[Matthew Prior] (whose signature is omitted) to the E of M, asking for the Earl's good offices in the presentation to the library of the King of France of a Horace printed at Cambridge, and in a contemplated purchase of Greek types. (Printed, not quite correctly, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 118) Whitehall
The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, on the recall of Mr. Stanyan, and the expenses of the Embassy. Whitehall
Matthew Prior to the E of M, on parliamentary business, etc. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 121) Whitehall
Matthew Prior to the E of M, on parliamentary business, the prospects of parties, etc. (Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 122) Whitehall

M. Van Vryberge to the E of M, recommending the case of the Sieur de Rodon, one of the King's officers and a native of Orange, and mentioning enclosure of his memorial. The journey [of William III] to Holland was not, and probably would not be, spoken of until the proceedings of the Scotch Parliament were known. (In French) London

The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, instructing the latter to renew his representations at the French Court with regard to the necessity of preserving the peace in the North, and announcing that "the great affair was quite finished," etc. (Partly in cipher. Printed, without the part in cipher, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 122) Whitehall

Matthew Prior to the E of M, on the presentation of the Cambridge Horace, on the desire of the University of Cambridge to be furnished with Greek types from France, on the recall of Mr. Stanyan, etc. (Printed, in part only, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 124) Whitehall

The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, instructing the latter to act in concert with M. de Torcy respecting the notification of "the affair" at Vienna and Madrid, etc. (Partly in cipher, deciphered. Printed, as deciphered, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 124) Whitehall
Matthew Prior to the E of M, expressing "My Lord's" [the Earl of Jersey's] regret at not having yet had an opportunity of speaking to the King "to be" the E of M's "gossip."

The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, giving instructions on various matters, and mentioning the alleged plot. (Partly in cipher, deciphered. Printed, as deciphered, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 126) Hampton Court
H. Greg to the E of M, touching the goods of English subjects seized on the Danzig ships, and mentioning enclosures. (Printed, almost entire, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 123) Copenhagen
Matthew Prior to the E of M, referring to the "great affair," Sir William Ellis, Lord Chief Justice Holt, etc. (Partly in cipher. Deciphered and printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 128) Hampton Court
J. Robinson to Mr. Stanyan, giving an account of military and naval movements. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 128) Stockholm
James Cressett to the E of M, to the effect that whatever was undertaken by Danes or Saxons was concerted at Berlin. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 125) Berlin

The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, conveying the King's approval of the E of M's past proceedings in his Embassy, and giving instructions on various points to guide his future conduct. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 131) Whitehall

The E of M to Mr. Stanhope (then at the Hague), on the complications in the North, and asking for information with respect to the intentions of the Muscovites, which were considered of great importance. At the top is a note by the Earl: "This should come before the letter to the Earl of Jersey, dated, Paris, May 8, 1700." (Draft) Paris
On the same paper is a draft of a letter from the E of M to Mr. Cressett, on the same subject, with mention of a report that the Muscovites intended to assist the King of Poland. Paris
J. Robinson to Mr. Stanyan, giving an account of military and naval movements in the North, and stating that the Czar would probably not interfere. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 134) Stockholm
James Cressett to the E of M, stating that there was much ill will against the King of England at Berlin, and expressing a wish to be recalled. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 128) Berlin
The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, respecting the interpretation of an article in the Treaty of Partition in certain eventualities. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 135) Hampton Court

Alexander Stanhope to the E of M, expressing hopes that the King of Denmark would be brought to agree to a reasonable peace, and that neither the King of France nor the Czar had hostile intentions. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs p. 129) The Hague

James Cressett to the E of M, stating that all he could obtain from the Court of Berlin (which he was leaving) was a very doubtful neutrality, and giving an account of some movements in the North. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 133) Berlin

The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, informing him that the Elector of Brandenburg had been making overtures "underhand" to France, in favour of Denmark and Poland, and instructing him how to proceed. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 138) Hampton Court
The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, giving instructions on various subjects. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 139) Hampton Court
James Cressett to the E of M, describing the approach of the Swedes and Lunenburghers, and expressing a belief that the Danes would soon change their tone. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 137) Hamburg

The E of M to the Earl of Jersey, giving an account, at some length, of conversations with M. de Torcy and others, at Paris, on the subject of affairs in the North, and other matters, and expressing confidence in the good faith of the French Court. (Draft, p. 6. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 141) Paris

Alexander Stanhope to the E of M, expressing delight at the probable "agony" of the Pope and the Spaniards when the Partition Treaty was made known to them, and giving some particulars on the state of affairs in the North. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 140) The Hague

M. Plantamour to the E of M, on affairs in the North, and especially on the movements of the Elector of Hanover, and the Duke of Zell, and the probable relief of Toninghen by the Lunenburghers. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 140) Berlin
James Cressett to the E of M, on affairs in the North, with especial reference to the refusal of French mediation by the Duke of Holstein. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 142) Hamburg
The E of M to the Earl of Jersey, chiefly on the state of affairs in the North. (Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 143) Paris

M. Plantamour to the E of M, announcing that orders had been given for the march of troops to the Elbe, etc. (In French. A translation, however not quite complete, is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 144) Berlin
Project for an Armistice of fifteen days between the King of Denmark and the Guarantor of the Treaty of Altona. (In French) Pinnenberg

James Cressett to the E of M, to the effect that neither Denmark or Holstein was willing to accept the mediation of France apart from that of the Emperor, and that an engagement between the Danes and the Allies appeared imminent. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 144) Hamburg
Paul Methuen to Mr. Stanyan, giving an account of the reception of the news of the Partition Treaty by the King of Portugal. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 144) Lisbon
The E of M to the Earl of Jersey, on the mode of communicating the Treaty to the minor German Courts, and other matters. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 145) Paris
Robert Sutton to [the E of M], expressing an opinion that the Emperor, though displeased with the Partition Treaty, had not yet formed any resolution upon it. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 146) Vienna

The E of M to the Earl of Jersey, suggesting the expediencey of apprehending certain persons, and giving some particulars of Northern affairs. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 146) Paris
The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, on the conditions upon which the Emperor and Portugal would "come to" the Partition Treaty, and giving instructions on various matters. Hampton Court
James Cressett to the E of M, on Northern politics. (Printed, not quite correctly, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 147) Pinnenberg
The E of M to the Earl of Jersey, on the affairs of the Prince de Montbeliard, the doings at St. Germain's, etc. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 147) Paris

M. Lubières to the E of M, requesting the good offices of the latter with M. de Torcy in the case of M. de Rodon (against whom there had been some misrepresentations made by his enemies, as well as on behalf of "le nommé François Vial," who had been detained three months in prison, and had been a resident in Orange since 1665. (In French) Orange
Alexander Stanhope to the E of M, on the communication of the Partition Treaty to the Powers, and on the policy of the Czar. (Printed. Cole'd Memoirs, p. 148) The Hague
R. Yard to the E of M, announcing that the Earl of Jersey had succeeded the Duke of Shrewsbury as Lord Chamberlain, etc. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 155) Whitehall

The E of M to the Earl of Jersey, on the mode of reception of the Treaty of Partition by the various Powers, on affairs in the North, on the case of the Prince de Montbeliard, etc. (Draft, 7 pages. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 149) Paris

M. Plantamour to the E of M, announcing a change of policy at the Court of Berlin, which had withdrawn its support from Denmark, and recommended that Power come to terms. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 151) Berlin

James Cressett to the E of M, complaining of the partiality of the French Ambassador towards Denmark, and giving an account of the state of affairs in the North. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 152) Pinnenberg
The E of M to Mr. Prior, promising to let the Earl of Jersey know, by a subsequent letter, what was occurring. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 152) Paris

The E of M to the Earl of Jersey, on the case of the Prince de Montbeliard, on Venetian affairs, on the publication of the Treaty of Partition, etc. (Draft. Incomplete. For conclusion see 30. Printed, with some variations, under date July 8th, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 156) Paris
Alexander Stanhope to the E of M, on the state of affairs in the North. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 153) The Hague
James Cressett to the E of M, giving an extract from a despatch on Northern affairs and policy, which had been sent to Mr. Vernon. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 153) Hamburg
The E of M to the Earl of Jersey, mentioning an enclosure relating to news brought by recent letters from Spain. (Draft) Paris
Also, on the same sheet of paper, draft of letter from the E of M to Mr. Prior, stating tha "Col. Slinsby" had gone to England, possibly with the consent of the Government. Paris

The E of M to the Earl of Jersey, on the Emperor and the Treaty of Partition, affairs in the North, the cases of M. de Rodon and the Prince de Montbeliard, etc. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 156) Paris
J. Robinson to the E of M, giving copy of letter of same date to "Mr. Secretary [Vernon], on affairs in the North, especially the movements of the fleets. (Printed, Cole's Memoirs, p. 164) Malmöe
The E of M to the Earl of Jersey. (Part of a draft asking for employment for Mr. Stanyan. It seems to be the conclusion of 23)

James Vernon to the E of M, on the case of the ship "William and Jane," seized by the French on the coast of Africa, on the state of affairs in the North of Europe, and on the Scottish Parliament. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 168) Whitehall
James Cressett to the E of M, forwarding particulars (as sent to Mr. Secretary Vernon) relating to the affairs in the North. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 157) Hamburg
Copy of Memorial presented by the French Ambassador to the Diet at Bâle, announcing the conclusion of the Partition Treaty. (In French) Bâle
The E of M to Mr. Prior, regretting that the Earl of Jersey and Mr. Prior had left their offices. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 159) Paris

Undirected and unsigned letter, beginning "Sir," giving some particulars of affairs in the North, and indicating the reserve of the Court of Vienna on the subject of the Partition Treaty. (Printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 160, as part of a despatch of the same date from Mr. Sutton, in whose handwriting it appears to be, to the E of M. See 44.) Vienna
The E of M to the Earl of Jersey. (Draft on the end of letter 38. See below.)
James Vernon to the E of M, asking for information repecting the movements of "the assassins," etc. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 173) Whitehall

The E of M to the Earl of Jersey, mentioning enclosure from Mr. Cressett, giving some account of the proposed mediation in the North, and the probable reception of the Partition Treaty by the Swiss, etc. (Draft, imperfect. See 36. The whole letter is printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 162.) Paris

M. Hervart to the E of M, on the approaching Diet at Soleure and the reception of the Partition Treaty by the Swiss. (In French. A translation, under the date 7/18 July, is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 164.) Berne [Bern]

James Vernon to the E of M, on the seizure of English ships by the French, off the coast of Africa, the slave trade, and other matters affecting mercantile marine, etc. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 174) Whitehall
James Cressett to the E of M, announcing that the Danes had at length consented to treat, and giving some particulars of affairs in the North. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 174) Whitehall

Copy of a statement (unsigned, but for which Mr. Robinson was probably responsible), giving an account of the movements of the Swedish fleet, the protests of Admiral Guldenlew, and interviews with him, etc. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 165) Allies' camp, near Oldeslo

Copy of an address to the "Gran Duca" [of Tuscany?], announcing the conclusion of the Partition Treaty. (In Italian. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 178. where the document is described as "Sir Lambert Blackwell's Speech.")

R. Sutton to the E of M, mentioning enclosed advices, and expressing an opinion that the Emperor would give his good offices towards securing peace in the north, and would not take active measures to prevent the execution of the Partition Treaty. (Printed, under date July 10, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 160. See 35) Vienna
The E of M to the Earl of Jersey, mentioning an enclosure, and the acceptance of mediation by King of Denmark. (Copy) Paris

Extract from a letter from M. le Comte de Chamilly to some unnamed person at Hamburg, mentioning a promise of a favourable answer from the King of Denmark, but expressing doubts on the subject. The letter was to be communicated to the Abbé Bidal.

Alexander Stanhope to the E of M, referring to an enclosed abstract of letter from Mr. Robinson, and making some remarks on Northern affairs. (Printed, not quite correctly, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 169) The Hague

Abraham Stanyan to the E of M, on the subject of Broccard's salary, and announcing that Mr. Montagu would write to him by Lord Kingston, whom "several knights and Kitt Catters" attended to his yacht. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 181) London
R. Yard to the E of M, on the Darien capitulation and the state of feeling in Scotland. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 181) Whitehall
Cavaliere Coriolano Montemagni to the English Envoy [Sir Lambert Blackwell], sending
the reply of the Grand Duke of Tuscany to the communication in which he was made acquainted with the Partition Treaty. (Copies. In Italian. Translations are printed in Cole's Memoirs, pp. 177-8)
Copy of the reply of the Grand Duke of Tuscany to the French Envoy on the subject of the Partition Treaty. (In Italian. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 178)

Sir Lambert Blackwell to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of his speech to the Grand Duke, and expressing an expectation of obtaining a more definite answer than he had yet received on the subject of the Partition Treaty. Florence
James Cressett to the E of M, on the state of affairs in the North, and mentioning enclosure of of a copy of a letter from M. de Chamilli. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 170) Hamburg

James Vernon to the E of M, on the English ships seized by the French off the coast of Guinea, and the claims of the African Company, and on the correspondence and agents passing between Scotland and St. Germain. (Partly in cipher, deciphered) Whitehall
William Blathwayt to the E of M, on the Danish difficulty, and mentioning enclosure relating to the position of the fleets. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 178) The Hague
Alexander Stanhope to the E of M, on the retreat of the Danish Fleet, the defeat of the Saxons, etc, with mention of enclosure. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 176) The Hague
James Cressett to the E of M, on politics in the North, and mentioning the bombardment of Copenhagen by Sir George Rooke. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 178) Hamburg

Sir Lambert Blackwell to the E of M, mentioning enclosures already described, under date July 23, viz., answers of the Grand Duke of Tuscany to the English and French Envoys on the subject of the Partition Treaty. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 177) Florence
The E of M to the Earl of Jersey, suggesting the expediency of an interview with the King at Loo. (Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 179) Paris

M. Hervart to the E of M, informing him that the Swiss Cantons were contriving to gain time before giving an answer on the Guarantee of the treaty of Partition, etc. (In French. A translation of the chief part is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 180) Berne [Bern]
James Vernon to the E of M, on the various political topics of the day. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 193) Whitehall

James Cressett to the E of M, expressing hopes that a just and reasonable peace might be signed at the Hague, and concluding thus: "I have personell as well as politick reasons to lang for peace, for no dog can be more tyr'd with bearbaiting than I am." (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 184) Hamburg

The E of M to the Lord Chamberlain [Earl of Jersey], mentioning an enclosure, and touching very briefly on conversations with M. de Torcy respecting the Partition Treaty, and the views of Portugal on the subject. "The only discourse we have here is bombarding the Danes," he says; "it is certain nothing else will do." Paris
James Cressett to the E of M, announcing that a despatch had been sent to the King with news of a successful landing of Swedish forces near Elsinore. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 186) Hamburg
Alexander Stanhope to the E of M on Northern affairs, and stating that Riga was threatened by the King of Poland. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 189) The Hague
James Cressett to the E of M on affairs and prospects in the North. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 190) Hamburg
Paul Methuen to the E of M, announcing that a Treaty of Guarantee (relating to the Partition Treaty) had been signed on behalf of the King of Portugal. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 192) Lisbon
M. Hervart to the E of M, on the attitude of the Swiss with regard to the Partition Treaty. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 194) Berne [Bern]
R, Sutton to the E of M, announcing that the Emperor had definitely refused to accede to the Partition Treaty. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 194) Neustadt
William Blathwayt to the E of M, expressing a belief that the Treaty to be signed within a few hours near Segeberg would put an end to hostilities in the North. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 198) Loo
James Cressett to the E of M, announcing the signature of a Treaty of Peace at Travendal. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 199) Segeberg
William Blathwayt to the E of M, announcing the conclusion of the peace in the North, and mentioning an enclosure in which the principal points were set forth. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 199) Loo

James Cressett to the E of M, sending a copy of a despatch to Mr. Blathwayt. In the latter are given some particulars relating to the manner in which the Treaty of Travendal was concluded, and mention is made of an "Act signed sub spe ratificationis." (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 200) Hamburg

William Blathwayt to the E of M, instructing him to make complaint to M. de Torcy respecting the arrest of Mr. Chetwynd at Valenciennes as a breach of the privilege of Foreign Ministers. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 201) Loo

J. Robinson to the E of M on the Treaty of Travendal, the renewed menace of the Danes, and the slowness of the Swedish Court in acceding to the Partition Treaty. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 205) Helsingborg

Postscript to a letter from J. Robethon to [the E of M], on the religious difficulties in Orange and the case of M. Blisson, who was anxious to pass into Holland. It is in reply to a letter from the Earl dated Jan. 29. (In French)

The E of M to the Lord Chamberlain [Earl of Jersey], on the refusal of the Emperor to accede to the Partition Treaty, and on the case of Count Boscelli [Bosselli], on which instructions are requested. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 202) Paris
William Blathwayt to the E of M on Mr. Chetwynd's arrest, on the Emperor and the Treaty of Partition, and on affairs in the North. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 203) Loo

M. Hervart to the E of M, announcing that the Diet of the Cantons would be held on the 19th of the same month, for the consideration of the Partition Treaty. He also enquires in what manner it would be right for him to go into mourning for the Duke of Gloucester. (In French.) Berne [Bern]

William Blathwayt to the E of M, instructing him to make the King of France acquainted with the desire of the English that there should be a pacification between Sweden and Poland. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 204) Loo

James Cressett to the E of M, sending a copy of a letter "to Court," in which he recommends the demolition of the Hittler fort in the Elbe - a question submitted to the arbitrage of England, France, and Holland. (printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 207) Hamburg
James Cressett to the E of M, announcing his departure from Hamburg to press the Court of Lunenburg to accede to the Partition Treaty. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 210) Hamburg

M. Schonenberg to the E of M, on the attitude of Spain in respect of the admission of foreign troops into the Italian dominions, and on dissentions concerning the Spanish succession. (In French. A translation of the principal part is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 211) Madrid

The E of M to the lord Chamberlain [Earl of Jersey], mentioning enclosure from M. Schonenberg, and asking for instructions respecting the mode of notifying the death of the Duke of Gloucester at the French Court, etc. (Draft. The principal part is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 211) Paris

The E of M to Mr. Stanhope, mentioning enclosures, of which one was from M. Schonenberg. One for Mr. Blathwayt should not be delayed. They were supposed to refer to the entry of Imperial troops into Spanish territory in Italy. (Copy) Paris
On the same paper is a copy of a letter to Mr. Blathwayt, also mentioning enclosures.

The E of M to the Lord Chamberlain [Earl of Jersey], asking what were the King's intentions with respect to the appointment of Exempt of the Guards, for which he wished to recommend an officer. He also mentions a report that the Elector of Brandenburg was to be declared King of Prussia upon condition of furnishing 8,000 men to the Emperor against Italy. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, and without the part relating to patronage, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 209) Paris
M. Hervart to the E of M, announcing that the Swiss had declined to accede to the Partition Treaty. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 213) Soleure

The E of M to M. Schonenberg, expressing thanks for information respecting the Spanish Court, and a belief that the good understanding between France and England would continue. (Draft, in French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 214) Paris

The E of M to Mr. Methuen, announcing that the Electors of Hanover and Brandenburg would shortly meet the King at the Hague, and that there was a probability of the enlargement of the Act for the settlement of the English Crown. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's memoirs, p. 214) Paris

James Cressett to the E of M, giving some details of the manner in which he had "carried his pack of Spanish merchandise [the Partition Treaty] about with him from Court to Court, "and yet did not see many customers fond of it." (Six pages. Printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 214) Zell

M. Robethon to the E of M, giving instructions respecting the delivery of an "ordonnance visée" to the bearer of the King's order and touching upon various other matters affecting the principality of Orange. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 216) Loo

James Vernon to the E of M, mentioning briefly Sir Charles Duncombe and the Court of Aldermen, Lord Bradford's illness, etc, and asking for copies of accounts (about to be reprinted by the Court of St. Germains) of the death of King Charles, and the Duchess of York in the Catholic Faith. Whitehall
Beginning of an unfinished and undirected letter written by the E of M, on the affairs of Orange. (In French) Paris
The E of M to Mr. Blathwayt on the reception, by the French King, of the notification of the death of the Duke of Gloucester. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 218)
The E of M to Mr. Stanhope, on the expected death of the King of Spain, and its probable consequences. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 220)

The E of M to the Lord Chamberlain [Earl of Jersey] on the expected death of the King of Spain, the attitude of the Emperor, the augmentation of the French army, the movements of the French Navy, etc. (Draft, pp. 7. Printed with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 218) Paris
Alexander Stanhope to the E of M, giving news of the march of the Czar to the assistance of the King of Poland against the Swedes, and other matters. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 221) The Hague
James Vernon to the E of M, on the expected arrival of the King of England and other topics. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 229) Whitehall

The E of M to Mr. Blathwayt, expressing his belief that the King of France was anxious to co-operate with the King of England in bringing the King of Poland and the Czar to terms of peace with Sweden, and announcing that the Elector of Brandenburg contradicted the report that he had engaged to support the Emperor with troops. (Draft, pp. 5. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 222) Fontainebleau
The E of M to Mr. Blathwayt, on various reports from Spain, etc. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 223) Fontainebleau
The E of M to Mr. Stanhope, mentioning some reports from Spain, the Polish difficulty, etc. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 222) Fontainebleau

The E of M to some French official, on the case of Mr. Hart, who had been delayed in France by the attempt of a woman to extort money from him. The Earl was reluctant to speak to M. de Torcy on the subject. (Draft. In French)
The E of M to Mr. Stanhope, stating that he had no further news. (Draft) Fontainebleau

The E of M to Mr. Blathwayt, on the attitude of the Emperor, and on the interpretation of the treaty of Oliva, by the Polish Envoy, with respect to the Courland forts. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 224) Fontainebleau
James Cressett to the E of M, giving a copy of a letter to Mr. Blathwayt on the continuance of dissentions in the North. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 225)
The E of M to Mr. Cressett, touching briefly on various points of European politics. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 225) Fontainebleau
The E of M to Mr. Stanhope, mentioning enclosures to the Lord Chamberlain and Mr. Blathwayt. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 229)

James Vernon to the E of M, instructing him not to encourage the Danes in any hopes of keeping the Hittler fort, and giving some particulars of home affairs. (Printed, with the variation of "Hether" for "Hittler," in Cole's Memoirs, p. 233) Hampton Court

M. Schonenberg to the E of M, informing him that the King of Spain, who in the extremity of his illness had been persuaded to sign a will in favour of the second son of the Dauphin, had, upon his recovery, shown great indignation against the ministers who had advised him. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p 226) Madrid

M. Schonenberg to the E of M, informing him that the King of Spain had signed another will or codicil, of which the purport was kept secret, but in which it was supposed that he had named the Archduke Charles of Austria his successor. (In French. A translation of a portion only is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 228) Madrid
Alexander Stanhope to [the E of M], expressing a belief that the King of Poland was willing to make peace with Sweden, etc. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 227) The Hague
William Blathwayt to the E of M, mentioning an enclosure which would show what were his Majesty's "intended motions," etc. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 228) The Hague
The E of M to the Lord Chamberlain [Earl of Jersey] on Spanish affairs, military movements of the French, etc. (Draft. Printd, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 228) Fontainebleau
The E of M to Mr. Montagu, expressing anxiety about the next Session of Parliament, and repeating some details given in other letters. (Draft) Fontainebleau
H. Greg to the E of M, on the delay of the Danish King to accede to the Partition Treaty, and various affairs in the North. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 230) Copenhagen

R. Sutton to the E of M on the reluctance of the Emperor to accede to the Partition Treaty, with details, at some length, respecting the position and resources of the Empire. (6 pages. Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 231) Vienna

The Earl of Jersey to the E of M, giving instructions respecting proposed modifications of the Treaty of Partition, in favour of the Duke of Savoy. (Partly in cipher, deciphered. Printed, as deciphered, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 238) Whitehall
M. Schonenberg to the E of M, announcing that the King of Spain had had an alarming relapse. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 232) Madrid

James Vernon to the E of M, instructing him to bring to the notice of M. de Torcy certain practices of the Indians sanctioned by the Governor of Canada, and giving an account of the trial of 90 French pirates at the Admiralty Sessions, etc. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 238) Whitehall

M. Schonenberg to the E of M, informing him that the King of Spain was not expected to live through the night, and that certain powers had been given to Cardinal Portocarrero. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 233) Madrid

M. Blisson to the E of M, requesting the latter to interest himself on behalf of M. Blisson who was unable to obtain a passport, who justified his past conduct, and hoped he would not be abandoned after displaying much zeal and assiduity. (In French) Orange

James Vernon to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of the Secret Article by which the Emperor was allowed two months after the death of the King of Spain to decide whether he would accede to the Partition Treaty. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 243) Whitehall

The E of M to the Lord Chamberlain [Earl of Jersey] on Spanish affairs: to the effect that the French King was satisfied with the mode of partition but would consent to any reasonable alteration of the Treaty, if desired by the King of England. (Draft. Printed, with some variations and ommisions, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 234) Paris
Part of an undirected letter, in the handwriting of the E of M, on Spanish affairs, the relations of "the Elector" with the Emperor, etc.
Paul Methuen to the E of M, announcing that the King of Portugal had signed his Act of Accession to the Partition Treaty. (Printed, Cole's Memoirs, p. 235) Lisbon

James Vernon to the E of M, informing him that the King did not consider it expedient to make any change in the Partition Treaty until two months had elapsed after notification of the death of the King of Spain to the Emperor. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 244) Whitehall

M. Schonenberg to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of a packet for His Majesty, and announcing that upon the death of the King of Spain it was found that the Duc d'Anjou had been named successor by will. Other details are given, both of the will, and of the post mortem examination of the body of the King of Spain. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 235) Madrid
The E of M to M. de Lubières on the affairs of Orange, and expressing hopes of obtaining a passport for M. Blisson. (Draft in French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 236) Paris
James Cressett to the E of M, giving a copy of a despatch to Mr. Secretary Vernon on Northern affairs, and on the probability of Danish troops entering Saxony. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 237) Zell

Alexander Stanhope to the E of M on the interpretation of the Treaty of Travendal, and difficulties anticipated from the march of Danish troops into Saxony. (The principal part is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 241) The Hague

M. Schonenberg to the E of M, mentioning enclosure for the King, and giving an account of the attitude of the Queen Dowager of Spain, and the movements of French troops. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 245) Madrid

James Vernon to the E of M on the Partition Treaty, and on the project for placing a French Prince on the throne of Spain. (Partly in cipher, with decipher on fly-leaf. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 248) Whitehall

James Cressett to the E of M, announcing the march of the Danes towards Saxony, and of the Swedes towards Wismar, and expressing an opinion that the conjuncture was important. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 247) Hanover

M. Schonenberg to the E of M, announcing the proclamation of the Duc d'Anjou as Phillip V, King of Spain, and giving various details of the situation. (In French. A translation of the greater part is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 255) Madrid

The E of M to Mr. Stanhope, announcing the expected departure of the Duc d'Anjou for Spain, and expressing fears that "the affairs of Europe were in a very ill condition." (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 255) Paris
Project of treaty for the settlement of the affairs of Orange as sent to M. Vryberge by Lord Portland. (In French)
J. Robinson to the E of M, giving a long account of the victory of the Swedes over the Muscovites. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 266) Stockholm

James Vernon to the E of M, directing him forward to an enclosed letter containing a copy of the instructions given to Dr. Aglionby who had been appointed to carry his Majesty's answer to a letter received from the Regency of Spain. The Earl was to forward this enclosure to M. Schonenberg as a precaution against the possible detention of Dr. Aglionby by adverse winds. Particulars are also given of a conversation Mr. Secretary Vernon and M. Tallard, chiefly on affairs connected with Spain. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 267) Whitehall

Alexander Stanhope to the E of M, announcing that the States had despatched their preliminary answer to the French King (in which they asked for time to arrive at a decision on matters connected with the Spanish succession) and expressing an opinion that it would be premature to take any action with respect to the Dutch troops in Flanders. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 259) The Hague
Matthew Prior to the E of M on the probability of a new Parliament being summoned, and on political prospects in general. (6 pages. Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 269) Whitehall

James Vernon to the E of M, giving some particulars of M. Tallard's interview with the King, and of the movements of Meers and Captain Magrath. (Partly in cipher, deciphered on fly-leaf. Nearly all printed, as deciphered, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 270) Whitehall

M. Schonenberg to the E of M, giving an account of the measures, military and otherwise, adopted by the Court of Madrid, with reflections upon the weakness of Spain. (In French. A translation of the principal part is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 263) Madrid
James Cressett to the E of M, giving a copy of a letter to Sir Charles Hedges on the politics of Brunswick, Zell, Hanover, etc. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 263) Zell
