J. Robethon to the E of M on the affairs of the Principality of Orange. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 265) Hampton Court

The E of M to Lord Halifax [late Mr. Montagu], complaining that his expenses had not been paid, and asking Lord Halifax to mention the matter to the E of J, who had more interest than ever with the King, and who had named the new Secretary. "I cannot," he says, "comprehend what we are doing, and what measures we intend to take with France." He wished to have "some light into affairs at home, and how people stood affected." Paris

The Earl of Albemarle to M. Schuylenbourg, directing him to give the necessary order to the King's Treasurer at Orange for an extra payment of 2,000 francs per annum to M. Lubières, the King's commandant there. (Copy. In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 266) Hampton Court

S. Edwin to the E of M on various social topics, with a mention of the promotion of Newton to be Master of the Mint. Mr. Montagu being "out of the Treasury" was "all over pleasure and making his house as fine as possible to entertain the ladies: particularly the bathing room is to be mightily finished with a fine field bed."
The E of M to M. Schonenberg informing him that the Emperor was preparing to enter Italy, but that the French troops would be there first. (Draft in French) Paris

M. Schonenberg to the E of M, expressing an opinion that the new King of Spain might be maintained in a reasonably independent position by the firmness of England and Holland, in spite of the conduct of the Regency. (In French. A translation of the principal part is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 274)
Representation of the British Minister to the Swiss Cantons on the subject of the Partition Treaty. (Copy in French, p.7)

Memorial of certain "confessors" to William III, praying him to make representations to the King of France, with the object of obtaining the release of persons sentenced to the galleys for their religion, who were said to suffer great hardships and cruelties. (In French. Endorsed "The French Protestant Remonstrance to the King.")
Draft project of Treaty of Peace between the Kings of Sweden and Poland, presented by M. du Heron, with amendments by M. de Beuchling, Chancellor of his Polish Majesty. (In French, p. 6)
Statement of the claims of the House of Montbeliard to the land and seignories of Henricourt, Blamont, and Châtelot in Burgundy. (In French)
James Vernon to the E of M touching briefly upon a variety of topics. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 283) Whitehall
Abstract of Treaty between the King and the States General, confirming the alliance of March 3, 1677/78, etc. The Hague
James Vernon to the E of M, giving instuctions on various matters, and some Home news. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 290) Whitehall

M. Schonenberg to the E of M, announcing the arrival of the new King of Spain at Irun, the expected retirement of the Queen Dowager of Spain to Toledo, the notice given to Count Auersberg to leave the Court of Madrid, the Count's acceptance of it as a declaration of war, etc. (In French) Madrid
James Vernon to the E of M, mentioning a report of the occupation of Nieuport by the garrison of Dunkirk, etc. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 225) Whitehall
James Vernon to the E of M, telling him that the occupation of Ostend and Nieuport by French troops had given great alarm in England. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 301) Whitehall

Alexander Stanhope to the E of M, giving an account of preparations for the withdrawal of the troops of the Duke of Bavaria from Brussels, in anticipation of the occupation of that city and other places by the French, and expressing a belief that the conjuncture was very critical. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 221) The Hague
J. Robethon to the E of M on the affairs of Orange. (7 pages. In French. Endorsed "These letters were left out." See No. 697. Third Division.) Hampton Court

The E of M to M de Torcy, to the effect that he had been empowered by the States General to make some representations in their name, for which purpose he would visit M. de Torcy on the following morning. (Draft in French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 293) Paris
James Vernon to the E of M, giving some account of an interview between M. Tallard and the King, and of other matters. (Printed, almost in full, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 380) Whitehall

James Vernon to the E of M, giving an account of the King's anxiety respecting the Dutch troops in Flanders, (where the inland towns had been occupied by the French) and of an interview of the King with M. Tallard upon the recall of the latter. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 302) Whitehall

James Cressett to the E of M, expressing fears that the affairs of Holstein would soon be again "embroiled in earnest," and giving some minute details respecting the actions and intentions of the Northern and some of the minor German Courts. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 295) Hamburg

James Vernon to the E of M, informing him that the French would permit the Dutch troops to leave Flanders, but expressing suspicions of French military and naval preparations. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 313) Whitehall

The E of M to Mr. Stanhope, expressing fears that the intentions of the French were not pacific, and regretting that some despatches had fallen into the hands of the Regents of Spain through an accident to his messenger, Mr. Jolly. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 300) Paris
James Vernon to the E of M, on the approaching meeting of Parliament and various other subjects. (The greater part is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 315) Whitehall

James Vernon to the E of M, informing him that the King had communicated to the House of Commons a Memorial in which the States General acquainted His Majesty that they had resolved to acknowledge the King of Spain, and requested His Majesty to have succours in readiness, in accordance with existing treaties. The King had also communicated to both Houses a letter of the Earl of Melfort to the Earl of Perth, disclosing schemes for an invasion, etc. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 319) Whitehall

James Vernon to the E of M, giving a long account of an interview with M. Tallard (who had expostulated against the communication of the Earl of Melfort's letter to Parliament), the purport of the despatches lost through the death of Mr. Jolly, etc. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 322) Whitehall

James Vernon to the E of M to the effect that there was a "good accord" between the King and the Parliament, and that preparations for defence (in the event of war) would be made with all diligence. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 325) Whitehall

James Vernon to the E of M on Lord Melfort's letter, on the proposed enlargement of the succession, and on some untrue reports of a league between England, Holland, and the Empire. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 329)
James Vernon to the E of M, informing him of negotiations to be carried on at the Hague, and of naval preparations made in England. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 331) Whitehall
James Vernon to the E of M, giving him some instructions and some items of news. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 335) Whitehall
M. Schonenberg to the E of M, on French influence in Spain, the attitude of Portugal, military movements, etc. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 327) Madrid
The E of M to Mr. Stanhope, on the negotiations at the Hague and the political prospect in general. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 333) Paris

James Vernon to the E of M, on the reception of the Partition treaty by Parliament, the suspicious conduct of the French, a grievance of the African Company against them, and the case of Count Boscelli [Bosselli]. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 350) Whitehall
A.S. [Alexander Stanhope] to the E of M, giving some account of the proceedings at the Conference at the Hague. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 338) The Hague
James Vernon to the E of M, giving further particulars of the opinion of the Lords upon the Partition Treaty, etc. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 348) Whitehall
Alexander Stanhope to the E of M, informing him that the French regarded the demands of England as unreasonable. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 346) The Hague

James Vernon to the E of M, informing him that the King had laid before the House of Commons a Memorial from M. Geldermalsen to the effect that the States were threatened with a sudden attack, and desired succours from England in accordance with the Treaty of [16]77. (Printed, not quite correctly, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 356) Whitehall

M. Robethon to "Messieurs du Chapitre" of Orange, recommending them to come to an amicable settlement with the Consistory. (In French. Copy. It is followed by a copy of M. Vryberghe's [Vryberge] Attestation enclosed in the original. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 360) London

M. Schonenberg to the E of M, announcing that the public entrance of the new King into Madrid had been fixed for the 14th of April, and giving some particulars of Spanish finance, military movements, etc. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 353) Madrid

James Cressett to the E of M, expressing an opinion that the King of Denmark and the Duke of Holstein would "jangle to eternity," but would not yet come to blows, and adding that the presence of the Danish troops in Saxony caused some disquiet in respect of Zell and Hanover. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 353) Zell

The E of M to Mr. Stanhope, informing him that the Duke of Savoy had signed the Treaty with France, that the French troops were advancing towards Venice, and that there was a rumour of a Treaty between France, Spain, and Portugal, to exclude English and Dutch ships from Portuguese ports in case of war. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 360) Paris
James Vernon to the E of M, instructing him to press M. de Torcy for the release of "the St. Lo yacht" and her commander. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 370) Whitehall

James Vernon to the E of M, mentioning enclosures of answers of the Admiralty to complaints of France, and giving some particulars of Home affairs. (Printed, with a paragraph not existing in the original, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 374. See 35) Whitehall

Sheet of paper with writing in cipher, deciphered to the effect that a decisive alliance with England and the States General would be proposed to the King of Portugal, and that his answer would show how far he was engaged "the other way." (Printed, as portion of the preceding letter, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 374)
James Vernon to the E of M, touching briefly on various topics. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 376) Whitehall
James Vernon to the E of M, touching briefly on various topics. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 377) Whitehall
A.S. [Alexander Stanhope] to the E of M, on the conduct of M. d'Avaux in the matter of negotiations between the States General and France. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 371) The Hague

M. Schonenberg to the E of M, announcing the proposed marriage of the Princess of Savoy with the new King of Spain, and giving an account of the property found on the person of M. Jolly, the Earl's Gentleman of the Horse [who had been drowned]. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 374) Madrid
Alexander Stanhope to the E of M, informing him that M. d'Avaux had presented a memorial to the States which was of a conciliatory nature. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 376) The Hague

James Vernon to the E of M, touching various topics and especially a "protestation" of the Envoy of Savoy in the name of the Duchess of Savoy "for asserting her right to succeed to the Crown after His Majesty and the Princess" [Anne]. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 354) Whitehall

James Vernon to the E of M, informing him that the King had no intention that England or the States should be separated from the Emperor to whom reasonable satisfaction might be given. Some instructions for his conduct in relation to this matter and some particulars of Home affairs are added. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 394) Whitehall

The E of M to the Earl of Albemarle. "I took the liberty to trouble your Lordship some time since, and I do not doubt but you have mentioned what I desired to his Majesty." The Earl concludes with a suggestion that he should have an interview with the King at Loo. (There is an endorsement, and a note elsewhere, to the effect that the letter was not sent. The sheets are bound in the wrong order.)

M. Schonenberg to the E of M, informing him of the discontent among all classes of Spaniards at the prospect of foreign domination, and giving some particulars of the French squadron at Cadiz, the Spanish Navy, etc. (In French. The conclusion, wanting in its proper place, is attached to M. Schonenberg's letter of Sept. 8, 1701. See 48. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 399) Madrid

M. Schonenberg to the E of M, asking to be furnished with immediate information as soon as a rupture with France became inevitable, (in order that British traders in Spain might receive timely warning), and giving particulars relating to the French fleet and the general condition of affairs in Spain. (In French. 6 pages. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 404) Madrid

M. Robethon to the E of M, on the claims of Madame Isanghyen and her determination to bring them before the Grand Council of Mechlin. (In French, 7 pages. A translation of nearly the whole is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 413) Loo
M. Lubières to the E of M, on the affairs of Orange, and the proposed arrangement with the Chapter. (In French) Orange

M. Schonenberg to the E of M, announcing the departure of the King of Spain to meet his future wife (the Princess of Savoy) the extraordinary powers entrusted to Cardinal Porto-carrero, and various other matters. (In French. The conclusion of a letter from the same to the same, dated July 14, (44) is attached. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 415) Madrid

Paul Methuen to the E of M, giving particulars of an interview with the King of Portugal, who, however, being encouraged by the appearance of a French fleet, had not been persuaded to explain his relations with France and Spain. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 423) Lisbon

M. Schonenberg to Mr. Secretary Vernon, giving a minute account of the miserable condition of Spain, the hopelessness of her finances, the defencelessness of her sea-board, and the advantages enjoyed by French artisans at the expense of the Spaniards. He recommended the strictest secrecy with respect to all measures to be taken against the growth of French domination. (In French. 7 pages) Madrid

M. Schonenberg to Mr. Secretary Vernon announcing that he had removed the Arms of England from his house, as the Spanish Court had recognised the pretended Prince of Wales, and asking for further instructions, as he was placed in a delicate and difficult position. (In French) Madrid

James Vernon to the E of M, on various topics, including an unexplained project of M. Lilierote [i.e. Lilienroot]. (Printed, with the exception of a paragraph in cipher, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 275) Whitehall

M. Schonenberg to Mr. Secretary Vernon, announcing that he was about to remove the Arms of England from his house, according to instructions (as the Spanish Court had recognised the pretended Prince of Wales) and giving some particulars of the want of money in Spain. (In French) Madrid
James Vernon, to the E of M on various subjects, all briefly touched. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 277) Whitehall

James Vernon to the E of M, announcing the arrival of the Emperor's Envoy in support of the Emperor's claim to the Spanish succession and the fief of Milan, and giving some particulars of the King's illness. (Partly in cipher, deciphered. Printed, as deciphered, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 278) Whitehall
The E of M to Mr. Robinson, expressing gratification at the defeat of the Muscovites, and a belief in a strong union between France and Spain. (Copy) Paris
The E of M to Mr. Stanhope to the same effect. (Copy) Paris
M. Schonenberg to the E of M, informing him that the Spanish Court was falling more and more under the influence of France. (In French) Madrid
Hugh Broughton to the E of M, on a great variety of subjects relating to Venetian and Italian affairs, etc. (6 closely written pages. A portion is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 282) Venice

Hugh Broughton to Soranzo and Venier, Ambassadors Extraordinary of the Republic of Venice in London, complaining that he had not, as British Consul, been received with due respect. Also on the same sheet of paper a portion of the same in Italian. Venice

Draft articles of agreement, respecting the navigation of the Gulf of Venice, exemption of British ships from payment of certain dues, etc, with remarks on the same. (In Italian. Six large and closely written pages)

Copy of a representation made by the E of M, on behalf of the Queen of England [Anne] to the Emperor, with the object of inducing him to grant investitures of the fief of Montferrat and other provinces to the Duke of Savoy, in accordance with the Treaty of Turin of 1703, and to repay a loan. (In French)

Draft or Copy of resolutions, respecting the constitution and pay of a garrison to occupy, on behalf of the Emperor, the fortress of Bitche, which belonged to the Prince de Vaudemont. (In French) Cologne

Passport of the States General of the United Netherlands for the baggage, equipage, etc, of the E of M, Ambassador of the Queen of Great Britain to the Republic of Venice. (In Dutch. Endorsed with visés also in Dutch) The Hague

Proposal of an Italian (probably Venetian) official for a conference with the British Ambassador on the subject "che per tutta l'Europa há causato tanto strepito," i.e. probably the Partition Treaty. (In Italian)

Copy of treaty between the Duke of Savoy and the Queen of Great Britain. (Partly in French, and partly in Latin. pp. 31. A translation of a portion, viz., the secret articles, is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 429) Turin
Memorial of the E of M to King William III, petitioning for arrears of pay due to him as late Ambassador in France.

Phillip [V], King of Spain, to the Queen Dowager of Spain, announcing that it would be necessary for her to retire to one of a number of towns to be indicated by him. (In French. Copy. An English translation "out of Spanish" is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 290) Tarias

Extract from the Register of Resolutions of the States General of the United Netherlands, being the answer of the States to the Memorial presented to them by the Comte Briord, Ambassador Extraordinary from France, in which he gave the reasons inducing the King of France to accept the will of the late King of Spain. (In French. An English translation "out of Dutch" is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 285
The same in Dutch. See above (3)
Instructions, under the King's sign manual, given by William III, to the E of M, upon the appointment of the latter as Ambassador Extraordinary in France. (Printed, Cole's Memoirs, p. 293) Kensington

Copy of Memorial to the King of France, embodying the reply of the States General already (3) mentioned. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 286, with the addition of the signature, "V. Heemskerk.") Versailles

Petition of Count Galeasse Boselly [Bosselli], an Italian, to the King of great Britain, praying that representations might be made to the French Court in favour of his release from the Bastille, in which he had been imprisoned on the charge of a plot against the said King. (In French)

Extract from the Register of Resolutions of the States General of the United Netherlands, being instructions to M. Heemskerk, Ambassador at the Court of France, to offer the French King a contradiction of reports spread abroad, that the States desired war, and an assurance that they were anxious to preserve peace. (In Dutch. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 294)
The same in French.

Letter, signed W., addressed to the King [apparently of England], and referring to some secret design, for the execution of which W. was very anxious that a sufficient sum of money should be remitted to him. (In French. 5 pages) La Cour de F[rance?]

Letters of Credence of the States General for the E of M, who was requested to represent them at the French Court during the illness of M. Heemskerk. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 295)

Memorial, presented to the King of France by the E of M on behalf of the States General, to the effect as the extract from their Register of Resolutions of the preceding 29th January (8). (Copy. In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 298) Versailles
Also on the same sheet of paper the substance of the answer of M. de Torcy to the same memorial. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 299)

The E of M to the States General, thanking them for the honour they had conferred upon him and their Letter of Credence, and informing them that he had presented a Memorial on their behalf. (Copy. In French. A translation is printed, without date, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 298) Paris

Memorial, presented to the States General by the Sieur de Quiros, the Spanish Ambassador Extraordinary at the Hague, offering explanations of the occupation of fortresses in the Spanish Netherlands by French troops acting as auxiliaries to the Elector of Bavaria, the Governor of the Spanish Netherlands, after the French King had decided to accept the will of the late King of Spain in preference to the Partition Treaty. (In French. Copy. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 305) The Hague
Another copy of the same.

The States General to the E of M, enclosing a copy of the Memorial of the Sieur de Quiros, and an extract of the Resolution taken upon it. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 307) The Hague

Extract from the register of Resolutions of the States General of the United Netherlands, (a reply to the memorial of the Sieur de Quiros, to be sent also to the Comte de Briord), disclaiming any warlike intentions which might have been inferred from the position of their troops in certain places in the Netherlands. (In French. See 19)
The same in Dutch, with two additional sentences. (A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 308)

Copy of the First Memorial of the Comte d'Avaux to the States General, expressing the desire of the King of France that peace should be maintained, and accompanied by a copy of a Letter of Credence (dated Feb. 2) to him as Ambassador Extraordinary. (In French. Translations are printed in Cole's Memoirs, pp. 311-312) The Hague

Copy of a Memorial of the Sieur de Geldermalsen, Envoy Extraordinary of the States General to the King of Great Britain, announcing that the States thought it necessary to proceed to the recognition of the Duc d'Anjou as King of Spain, and that they wished to act in concert with his Britannic Majesty, upon whose assistance they relied in the event of an attack upon them by France. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 320)

The E of M to the States General, giving an account of an interview with M. de Torcy (on the subject of the reply of the States General to the Sieur de Quiros), and of the pacific assurances then received. (In French. Copy. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 312) Paris

Extract from the Register of Resolutions of the States General of the United Netherlands, being the decision to inform the Comte d'Avaux that the States were willing to acknowledge the Duc d'Anjou as King of Spain, and hoped the King of France would consequently withdraw his troops from the Spanish Netherlands. (In French. An English translation "out of Dutch" is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 316)

The States General of the United Netherlands to the E of M, informing him that he had decided to recognise the Duc d'Anjou as King of Spain, and that the Sieur de Heemskerk would deliver the decision to the French Court. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 316) The Hague

Copy of a letter from the States General to the King of France, in which they acknowledge the Duc d'Anjou as King of Spain, and express their congratulations upon his accession. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 318)

Extract from the Register of Resolutions of the States General of the United Netherlands, being the resolution upon which the last-mentioned letter was founded. (In French. An English translation "out of Dutch" is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 318)

Copy of instructions to Alexander Stanhope, Esq., as Envoy Exraordinary to the States General, for the purpose of negotiating a treaty for the withdrawal of the French troops from the Spanish Netherlands. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 332) Kensington
Copy of the reply of the King of France to a letter addressed to him by the States General. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 324) Versailles

Copy of a letter from the E of M to the States General, giving some particulars of an interview with M. de Torcy, who had said that the French troops would be withdrawn from the posts in the Netherlands as soon as the King of Spain was in a position to provide for their defence himself. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 325) Paris

Copy of a Memorial of the Comte de Briord (the French Ambassador) to the States General, on the Occasion of taking his departure for the re- establishment of his health. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 341) The Hague

Extract from the Register of Resolutions of the States General of the United Netherlands, being the decision to communicate (in concert with Mr. Stanhope, the British Envoy Extraordinary) to the Comte d'Avaux, the articles of a projected treaty having for its object the withdrawal of the French troops from the Spanish Netherlands, and a general settlement which would be acceptable to all the parties to the Treaty of Partition from which the King of France had been withdrawn. (French. An English translation "out of Dutch" is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 341)

Propositions delivered to the Comte d'Avaux by Mr. Stanhope at the first conference with him. They are of the same purport as the document last mentioned. (In French. 6 pages. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 339)

Extract from the Register of Resolutions of the States General of the United Netherlands, relating to the sitting at which was received, from the Deputies of Foreign Affairs, a report of their conference with M. d'Avaux, who had told them it was necessary he should consult his master upon the subject of the proposal that the English should hold Niuport and Ostend, and the States certain other places as "places de sureté." (In French. An English translation "out of Dutch" is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 343)

Copy of a letter from Phillip V, King of Spain, to William III of England, announcing that he had obtained possession of the Spanish dominions, and expressing hopes that he might enjoy the friendship of the English King. (In Latin. A translation, of all but Phillip's full style and title, is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 334) Buen Retiro

Message of William III to the House of Commons, informing them of the apparent termination of negotiations between the States General and the King of France, and of the application made by the States General for assistance from England, according to the terms of the treaty of 3rd March 1677. (Printed in the Commons' journals, XIII, 402) Kensington

Abstract of the proposition of Count Schlick, General in the Emperor's Army, to the Electors of Cologne, asking them to aid the Emperor in the assertion of his claim to the Spanish monarchy, in the event of a rupture among the powers. It is followed by an abstract of the unfavourable reply of the Electors. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 356) Bonn

Copy of a letter from William III to Phillip V, of Spain, congratulating the latter upon his accession, and expressing good will, and hopes of lasting friendship. (In Latin. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 370) Kensington

Extract from the Register of Resolutions of the States General of the United Netherlands, being the decision to represent to the Comte d'Avaux their anxiety to secure the general peace of Europe as well as their own interests. (In French. An English translation "out of Dutch" is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 371)

Extract from the Register of Resolutions of the States General of the United Netherlands, being the decision to communicate to Mr. Stanhope the refusal of the Comte d'Avaux to consent to his presence, as representing British interests, at any conference in which the matters discussed related to the States General, though he might be present "pour seconder les interêts de cet Estat." (In French. This and the preceding document are fastened together, and the dates are reversed in their endorsements. An English translation "out of Dutch" is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 372)

Message of William III to the House of Commons, communicating to them a letter from the States General, and representing that the safety of England and the very existence of Holland were in danger. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 384) Kensington

Copy of a letter from the States General to William III, to the effect that they regarded the interests of their country and of England as inseparable, though the Comte d'Avaux had objected to the presence of Mr. Stanhope as representative of British interests at any conference affecting the interests of the States, that they perceived in his conduct a desire on the part of France to put an end to the negotiations, and that they were in urgent need of British succours, as there were already important movements of French troops. (In French. Seven closely written pages. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 379) The Hague

Copy of a Memorial of the Emperor's Envoy [Count Wratislaw], to William III, representing the alleged dangers threatening Europe, from the ambition of the King of France, and requesting aid in accordance with the treaty of 1689. (In Latin. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 385) London

Extract from the Resolutions of the Cirle of Suabia, being a reply to the Envoy Extraordinary of France (who had offered explanations respecting the march of French troops into Alsace, etc.) to the effect that Suabia and the whole Empire would be compelled to take up arms in defence, should any State belonging to, or dependent on the Empire be touched. It is stated, at the foot, that the French Envoy took his leave a few days after the receipt of this reply. (In French) Ulm
Abstract of the Secret Articles of the Treaty concluded with Denmark by England and the States General. (Printed, with some verbal variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 393) Copenhagen
Abstract of the Treaty between England, Denmark, and the States General. (pp. 5. Printed, with some verbal variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 391)
Abstract of a Convention between England, Sweden, and the States General. (Six short articles. 1 p.) The Hague
Abstract of the treaty between England, the Empire, and the States General. (Printed, with some verbal variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 416) The Hague

Copy of the letter of the E of M, announcing his recall upon the recognition of the Pretender by the King of France, and a copy of M. de Torcy's reply. (In French. Translations are printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 426)

[M. Vroese or Vroesen] to the E of M, mentioning the correspondence of a Jesuit in London (Father Plaud) with the French Court, and some military movements in Italy, whither the King of Spain had found it necessary to send reinforcements of his best troops. (In French) Paris

The Abbé Melani to the E of M, cautioning him against "Milord de Maleborath" [Marlborough], who had sent to make enquiries respecting the Earl's delay in leaving Paris, and giving an account of the hardships endured by the mother and wife of the Count Bosselli in the Bastille, where the Governor had made them suffer for the Count's escape. (In French. 7 pages) Paris

M. Schonenberg to Mr. Secretary Vernon, giving an account of the illness of the King of Spain, and of the recall (at the instigation of France) of certain officers from the Spanish army in Italy, who were supposed to be too favourably inclined to Austrian interests. He suggested, in a postscript, that when the time came for his own recall he should have Letters of Credence to the King of Portugal, who might be persuaded to act as the Allies desired. (In French) Madrid

M. Schonenberg to Mr. Secretary Vernon (but according to the endorsement "sent open to Lord Manchester.") He describes his successful efforts to protect the interests of British traders in Spain, the difficulty with which the Governor of Cadiz was restrained from firing at British frigates driven under the citadel by a violent storm, and the lethargy with which the Spanish nation abandoned itself to French influence. He had been questioned on the subject of the removal of the Arms of England from his house, and had not scrupled to give the real reason. (See vol. 6, No. 687, 53.) The French King had given assurance to the Spanish Ambassador that he would do everything in his power in support of his engagements, though not in a position to do as much as he desired. (In French. pp. 6) Madrid

M. Jurieu to the E of M. He and his co-religionists looked upon the King of England as a man chosen by God to abate the pride of tyrants, preserve the liberty of Europe, and spread the true religion. The King of England had quite as much right to uphold the Edict of Nantes as the King of France to interfere in the matter of the succession to the English throne. Letters had been sent to the principal Ministers of the State to the effect that God had not blessed previous treaties, because His interests had been altogether forgotten in them. The Earl was implored, on that and other accounts, to press upon the attention of the King the interests of Protestants abroad. Memorials on the subject had been sent to Mr. Secretary Vernon. (In French. 7 pages) Also postscript to the same, written on separate paper, so that while the letter could be shown to various persons, the "petites affaires" between Jurieu and the Earl would be kept to themselves. This relates to the amount and mode of remittance of money to be paid to Jurieu, and to M. Caillaud. The latter, it seems, undertook the "correspondences de France," but not the "correspondences de Flandre." The details had been arranged by Mr. Blathwayt and Mr. Vernon. The remittances, however, were not sent quite in accordance with the wishes of the "correspondents." (In French. 4 pages)
Memorandum relating to the affairs of Lithuania, including the death of the young Sapieha. (In French) Warsaw

M. Martine to [the E of M], promising to keep him informed of events which might occur at Paris, but pointing out that it would be necessary to take some precautions. Martine could not depend on any official position to enable him to send his letters openly, because he could not claim it on the ground of his employment in the service of the Republic of Geneva, and his employment in the service of the Court of Cassell would cease with the expected rupture. (In French) Paris
M. Schonenberg to Mr. Secretary Vernon, on the affairs of the Court of Spain. (In French. pp. 6) Madrid

M. Schonenberg to Mr. Secretary Vernon, referring again to the financial embarrassments of Spain, mentioning the delay of the British ships of war at Cadiz through stress of weather, and the rumour from France that the King of Spain was to command in Italy in person, and touching on some minor details of Spanish affairs. (In French. 6 closely written pages.) Madrid

Unsigned paper (possible sent by Martine, though not in his handwriting), giving information of the decision of the Council and King in France in favour of the departure of the King of Spain for Naples. The latter would probably go on afterwards to the Milanese, if, indeed, there were not found insuperable objections to the whole project at the last moment. Much surprise had been caused by the ready vote of 5,000,000 £ to the King in England. Various rumours which had reached the writer are mentioned, and among them one that the Princess of Denmark was pregnant. (In French.) Paris

John Cole to the E of M, on the affairs of Lithuania, where the families of Sapieha and Oginski had become reconciled (thus opening the way to peace between Sweden and Poland) on the negotiations of the Emperor with the Elector of Cologne, and on the warlike preparations in the Netherlands, where the Resolutions taken in England had given much encouragement. Amsterdam
M. Plantamour to the E of M, congratulating him on his appointment as First Secretary of State, and mentioning enclosure. (In French) Berlin
Enclosure, giving some particulars of news lately received at Berlin. (In French) Berlin

M. Martine to the E of M, suggesting that his letter should, for the sake of secrecy, be directed, under cover, to some person in trade. A little judicious expenditure might aid in the discovery of what was going on at Court. M. Martine was not in any way actuated by a regard for his own interest, and he would prefer to receive whatever the Earl might be pleased to give him, not in one sum, but as an annual salary. (In French) Paris

Paper (unsigned, and possible sent by M. Martine, but not in his handwriting), on French military affairs, and the projected expedition of the King of Spain to Naples and the Milanese, on the news from various parts of Europe, and especially from Italy, and the alarm excited in France by the attitude of England. (In French) Paris

M. Schonenberg to Mr. Secretary Vernon, giving an account of the alarm felt in Spain by the projected voyage of the King to Naples, of the refusal of the traders of Madrid to make a special contribution to meet emergencies, and of the hopeless condition of Spain in general. He mentions enclosure of a copy of a letter from the King of France to the King of Spain. (In French) Madrid

G. Stepney to the E of M, expressing hopes of the success of the Imperialists in Italy, and of the accession of the Archduke to the Crown of Naples, and asking for the Earl's influence that he might be appointed to bear the King's congratulations upon that event. Count Mansfeldt, the Austrian "President of War," had always lived in good correspondence with the Duke of Savoy, and still hoped he might "play his old game and change sides." It would therefore be expedient "so to manage Count Maffei as to keep open a door for reconcilement to which the Duke's natural love of change would contribute." Jordan was "like to go out in a snuff at Paris," as his master's "volatile spirit was at last fixed in favour of the Allies." Perhaps Bavaria would do the same after the vigorous resolutions of the English Parliament, which had inspired great confidence in Austria. An enclosure is mentioned. Vienna

Memorandum (endorsed "Stepney,") giving particulars of the Austrian troops destined for the expedition to Naples, against which the Nuncio, Prince Eugene, and the Envoy of Modena had remonstrated, as calculated to weaken the Imperial forces elsewhere. A draft treaty between the King of Poland and the Emperor for the supply of troops to the latter had been brought from Warsaw. Vienna

M. Schonenberg to Mr. Secretary Vernon, showing how completely Spain was under the influence of France, even to matters of ecclesiastical patronage, and how it would be through that influence that the King would set out for Naples, and giving some financial, military, and naval details. (In French. 7 closely written pages.) Madrid

"J.G." to "Mr. Hainning, at the Rt. Hon. the Earl of Portland's lodgings," giving an account of the news which had reached Paris of the surprise of Cremona, effected by Prince Eugene, and of his subsequent defeat by the French, though he had retained Marshal Villeroy as his prisoner. Paris

Alexander Stanhope to the E of M, expressing satisfaction with the great public spirit displayed by the Dutch, and their readiness for war. He touches on the humiliation of Marshal Villeroy, and the various probabilities of the political and military situation. Lord Albemarle had arrived. The Hague

M. Hervart to the E of M, on the attitude of the various Swiss Cantons with respect to the recognition of the Duc d'Anjou as King of Spain, and the efforts of the Marquis de Puisieulx, the French Ambassador, to obtain it. (In French) Bern

Etienne Caillaud to the E of M, informing him that the Comte de Breuille and a person named La Roche were supposed to have embarked at the Brill for London. It was expected that the address of La Roche in London could be obtained from his wife. The Earl was thanked for his protection of Caillaud's brother. The return of M. Coetlogon to Brest, without the galleons, which remained at Vera Cruz, would seriously derange the finances of Louis XIV. (In French) Rotterdam

Unsigned memorandum (by M. Hervart?) on the attitude of the Swiss Cantons in relation to Austria and to France. They had decided that they would not congratulate the Duc d'Anjou [on his accession to the throne of Spain]. The Marquis de Puisieulx had represented the affair at Cremona as advantageous to the French, and had, in consequence, been compared to the "Cuckold in the Comedy," who was beaten and content. (In French) Baden

M. Schonenberg to Mr. Secretary Vernon, on British subjects who had become naturalised in Spain, especially Francis Archer, a banker, said to be a violent Papist and a partisan of France, and a zealous supporter of the party opposed to "the rights of the legitimate succession in the Protestant line." (In French) Madrid

M. Schonenberg to Mr. Secretary Vernon, giving an account of the suspicions entertained in Spain that the Spanish King's intended voyage to Naples might be followed by his abandonment of Spain for the throne of Naples and Sicily alone, of the discontent general among all ranks in Spain, and of the difficulty in finding money for the public service. M. Schonenberg maintains the accuracy of the details in this and previous letters of the helpless condition of Spain, though the reports of some persons, and even of some consuls, might cause a different impression. The partisans of France were striving to inspire confidence in expectation of the return of the Mexican fleet. Their boasts would probably come to nothing, but the allies would do well to make a demonstration with promptitude. (In French. 7 pages) Madrid

Memorandum (unsigned) on the proceedings of the Swiss Cantons, including their resolution to accede to the demand of the Emperor for a levy of troops. The Protestant Cantons had decided that they would not recognise the Duc d'Anjou as King of Spain; the others held the question ad referendum. (In French) Baden
M. Hervart to the E of M, mentioning difficulties caused by the demand of the Canton of Zurich to nominate the Colonel of one of the regiments demanded by the Emperor from the Swiss. (In French) Bern
M. Hervart to the E of M, expressing an opinion that the Swiss Cantons would remain firm in their resolve not to recognise the Duc d'Anjou as King of Spain. (In French) Bern

M. Hervart to the E of M, expressing an opinion that the French Ambassador would be unsuccessful in the demand which he had made for a corps of 6,000 Swiss, according to the terms of the Treaty of Alliance, and giving some of his reasons. (In French) Bern
Joseph Shallett to the E of M, to the effect that the province in which he was had been drained of troops (for the intended campaign in Italy) and of money (which had been sent to France). Barcelona

G. Stepney to the E of M, calling attention to two points in an enclosed paper. He adds: "I must entreat your Lordship that what I write to you upon occasion may not interfere with Mr. Secretary in what relates to his province, and that he be left to relate to his Majesty all that I have to represent. Your Lordship is sensible this is a duty I owe him in his post, and if it should happen otherwise it might be a means of making him less favourable to me." Vienna

The enclosed paper to which reference is made above. The two points to which attention is called are: (1) The definitive sentence of the Pope (of which some details are given) in favour of the Elector Palatine in his dispute with the Duchess of Orleans. (2) The permission given by the Emperor to the King of the Romans "to make the campaign." He would command upon the Rhine, and the French would have full employment upon all hands. Vienna

M. Schonenberg to the E of M, pointing out the difficulty of finding anyone in Spain who would incur the danger of corresponding with the English Government, after a rupture had occurred, and M. Schonenberg had himself left Madrid. This suggestion that such a person could be found had been made by William III. (In French. Six closely written pages) Madrid

M. Schonenberg to the E of M, on the alarm and difficulties caused in Spain by the delay of the Spanish fleet in returning from Mexico, the exhaustion of the Spanish finances, and the uncertainty whether the King of Spain would undertake the voyage to Naples. (In French. 7 pages) Madrid

M. Schonenberg to the E of M, mentioning the departure of half a dozen English families under escort of the English man-of-war "Filborough," the restitution of papers taken from the Queen Dowager's confessor, the appearance of a comet, and other minor matters. (In French) Madrid

M. Schonenberg to the E of M. The King of Spain was about to embark for Italy, but without the young Queen. There was great embarrassment caused both to France and to Spain by the detention of the Mexican fleet. Spain was in a state of defencelessness both by land and by sea. The Danish army had received orders to leave Madrid. An enclosure is mentioned. (In French. 6 pages)

M. Schonenberg to the E of M, suggesting that when the time should come for leaving Madrid he should return by way of Portugal. The Government of the Netherlands approved of this route, and had sent him a Letter of Credence for the King of Portugal. He hoped the King of England would take the same view. An enclosure is mentioned. (In French) Madrid

M. Schonenberg to the E of M, requesting the latter to represent to the King that he was in urgent need of money for his ordinary and extraordinary expenses. His outlay had been very great, and there would be new calls upon him when he withdrew. (In French) Madrid

G. Stepney to the E of M, announcing the ratification of the article against the Pretender, and expressing some anxiety respecting the position of Prince Eugene in Italy, although the expedition to Naples had been deferred. (Partly in cipher) Attached is a memorandum giving the news which had reached Vienna of the progress of events in Europe. (pp. 5) Vienna

Etienne Caillaud to [the E of M], mentioning enclosure of a list of French vessels of war as existing in 1699, promising to send such information as he could obtain of changes in their number and disposition, and describing the great sorrow felt in the United Provinces at the death of King William. Some consolation, however, was found in the good disposition of the Queen, his successor, and of the English Parliament. (In French) Rotterdam
Richard Brown to the Mayor of Canterbury, demanding restitution of fees paid by him to the gaoler of the gaol to which the mayor had committed him. "The Venetian Ambassador's in St. James's Square"

The Abbé Melani to the E of M, expressing great regret at the death of King William. The French Court had gone into mourning for him as Stadholder of the United Provinces. The Abbé could assure the Earl that if Her Majesty would announce to the King of France the death of her predecessor, and her own accession, the period of mourning would be extended, and she would be acknowledged as Queen of England. Ministers who had been employed to bring about a good understanding between the two nations had fomented quarrels through a regard to their own interests. An attempt should now be made to establish between England and France "un honneste correspondence, laissant aux, Allemans à faire la guerre avec leur methode ordinaire." (In French) Paris

M. Hervart to the E of M, on dissentions among the different Swiss Cantons, especially with respect to the recognition of the Duc d'Anjou as King of Spain. The Canton of Lucerne had now recognised him, and might therefore have to provide him with forces for the defence of the Milanese. (In French) Bern
L. [Sir Lambert] Blackwell to the E of M, sending present of "graine tobacco" and an enclosure with the news from Naples to the first of April, and from Rome to the fourth of April. (pp. 5) Florence

Sir Lambert Blackwell to the E of M. The Grand Duke, Prince, and Princess [of Tuscany], were very uneasy because the King of Spain had not yet left Naples. News of a great action fought by Prince Eugene, who was watching Vendôme, might be expected. An enclosure is mentioned.
Memorandum giving the news from Naples up to April 8, from Rome up to April 11, from Pisa up to April 14, and from Leghorn up to April 14.

Sir Lambert Blackwell to the E of M, expressing his regret at the death of King William III, and his wish to be transferred to Venice, and mentioning an enclosure, which seems to be the above (47). Florence

Hugh Broughton to the E of M, expressing surprise that he had received no letter from his Lordship's office, and asking to be honored with instructions to communicate the death of King William and the accession of Queen Anne to the College. He was put to great charges, which the "perquisites by consulage" would not support in the event of war, and entreated the Earl to "patronise the propagating" his interest. There was good reason to suppose that his letters sent by way of Flanders had been delayed or intercepted since the French "turned out Prince Tassis [Taxis] at Brussels," and he suggested a remedy. He understood there would be no delay in Venice in acknowledging the Queen, as there had been in the case of her predecessor. Venice

Thomas Kirke to the E of M, informing him that the Emperor's Envoy was about to quit Genoa, because the Government of the Republic had refused to comply with a demand for money for the campaign in Italy. Genoa

Hugh Broughton to the E of M, giving various items of news, and among them the report of the English fleet being about to enter the Mediterranean. He was anxious to have a new commission from Her Majesty by the Earl's influence. He mentions the case of the Venetian Ambassador's messenger, who had been intercepted and sent to prison by the Mayor of Canterbury. (See letter of April 6, 42) Venice

G. Stepney to the E of M, on the ill effects of not having an English fleet in the Mediterranean (which might have hindered the passage of the Duc d'Anjou) on the design of the Emperor with respect to Italy, and on the difficulty of "bringing about" the Duke of Savoy. Some exchanges of territory for the last-named purpose had been suggested, but such propositions could hardly be entertained before the end of the war. Vienna

M. d'Ebeling (Envoy of Montbeliard) to the E of M, expressing hopes that England and the States General would support the re-establishment of His Serene Highness of Montbeliard in his sovereignty. (In French) The Hague

Sir Lambert Blackwell to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of copies in Italian and English of the Grand Duke's answer to Her Majesty's letter, duplicates of which had been previously sent under another cover. He depended on the Earl's influence to have credential letters for Venice added to letters for Florence. He would attend to Lord Kingston's and Sir Alexander Rigby's affairs and send the Earl's picture. He was in correspondence with Prince Eugene, to whom he had done a service in respect of some deserters, and whom he had requested to send "the journal of the camp, by every quick conveyance," to the Earl. He wished to be remembered to Lord Halifax. Florence

Sir Lambert Blackwell to the E of M, mentioning some enclosures, and among them a letter from Prince Eugene (with translation into English). The picture for the Earl of Kingston was of great value, and Sir Lambert parted with it purely to oblige him and the E of M. The copy for the latter might be put on board any man-of-war which came "so high" as Leghorn. The small merchant shipping there was not to be trusted to the value of 10 £. Sir Lambert again asked for credentials to Venice. Florence

M. Schonenberg to the E of M, expressing his belief that the appearance of a fleet of the Allied Powers would be required to bring Portugal to a satisfactory attitude, as the Portuguese ministers had entered into very close and almost indissoluble engagements with the French. He hoped the Danish Envoy at Madrid had by this time begun to send the Earl particulars of events in Spain. (In French) Lisbon

Prince Eugene of Savoy to Sir Lambert Blackwell, thanking him for a service rendered in respect of some deserters, and explaining the difficulties in the way of sending his diary to the E of M, as all matters relating to the diaries were issued from the German Chancery, and it would be a long process to translate them into either French or Italian. (In Italian) Imperial Camp at Curtotone

Hugh Broughton to the E of M, giving the news which had reached him from Naples up to May 9, and from Rome up to May 20, with particulars of military movements of the French and Germans in the State of Mantua, etc. Venice
M. Jurieu to the E of M, expressing his regret that the latter had been succeeded as Secretary of State by Lord Nottingham, with whom, however, he would maintain communication. (In French) Rotterdam

Hugh Broughton to the E of M, thanking the latter for the renewal of his commission and expressing fears that some difficulties might arise from the fact that the State of Venice had prevented an English ship, with eight English seamen on board, freighted by the Emperor's Ambassador, and carrying the Imperial colors, from leaving port. Venice
Hugh Broughton to the E of M, giving particulars of news received from Naples up to May 26, and from Rome up to May 27, with some details of the military movements, in Italy, etc. Venice
Hugh Broughton to the E of M, giving the news received at Venice from Naples up to May 30, and from Rome up to June 3, with some particulars of military movements. Venice
Hugh Broughton to the E of M, giving news from Naples up to June 6, from Rome up to June 10, and the particulars known at Venice, at the date of the letter, of military movements in Italy. Venice

Sir Lambert Blackwell to the E of M, thanking the latter for recommending Sir Lambert to Lord Nottingham, from whom he had received new credentials and instructions about Sir Alexander Rigby's business. He trusted the Earl had received the snuff. He refers again to his account with Lord Kingston and to the painting to be sent to the Earl. Florence
"Points to be debated" respecting the Ninth Electorate and the Empire.
Memorial drawn up for the purpose of inducing the British Government to support the Prince de Montbeliard. (In French. pp. 6)
Memorial drawn up for the purpose of inducing the Diet of Ratisbon to support the Prince de Montbeliard. (In French)
Memorial drawn up for the purpose of inducing the Swiss Cantons to support the Prince de Montbeliard. (In French)
Memorial drawn up for the purpose of inducing the Emperor and the States General to support the Prince de Montbeliard, upon the recommendation of the British Government. (In French)

Abstract of Treaty of Alliance concluded by the Emperor with the King of England and the States General, Sept. 17 [1701]. (In French. Printed. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 416. See also Vol. 8, No. 688, of this collection, 47)
Memorial concerning the difficulty raised by the Ministry of Lorraine with respect to the counties Bitche, Sarwarden, Bougenon, belonging to the Prince de Vaudemont. (In French)
Another copy of the same.
Address of the Lords and of the Commons to Queen Anne, and her answer respecting the treachery of William Gregg, and the general want of Secrecy in Mr. Secretary Harley's office.
"Some few Queries about the Preparatives of making way for a Prince of Wales in the year 1687, etc..."

A representation of the state of America given to the King by the Lords Commissioners of trade, etc, showing the respective situations, governments, strength, trade, etc, of the several "Plantations, on the Continent of America." (42 pages. Printed, in part, in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii., 394)

Paper unsigned and unaddressed, but probably drawn up by direction of Martine. It gives some particulars of French naval, military, and financial affairs. Madame de Maintenon was so careful to prevent the King receiving any news which might annoy him that she was beforehand with every one who had occasion to speak to him, and had recently been in the habit of instructing M. de Catinat as to what he should say. Mention is also made of the affair of Mirandola, for which M. de la Citardie was blamed. A number of men in disguise had been introduced into the place on pretence of a fair, after which "the Princess" had sent for Citardie and offered him a passport enabling him to retire with his battalion. She had made common cause with Prince Eugene, because the French were unable to protect her from the insults of the Germans. She was Regent during the minority of the young Prince, her grandson. It was said, there were orders for the arrest of De la Citardie. It was certain that Catinat had left [Paris?] on the 2nd; Prince Eugene was retreating and his troops going into winter quarters. The numbers of French, Spanish, and Savoyard troops intended for the expedition to Italy are stated. (In French, pp. 7) Paris
Copy of a letter from the King of France to the King of Spain, expressing strong approval of the expedition of the latter to Italy. (In French)
Another copy of the same.
A third copy of the same.

Translation of a notification of the Spanish Consul, Navarro, to the E of M, that the King of Spain had prohibited the importation into his dominions of any merchandise of the growth of the Emperor's countries. London
The same notification in French.

Copy of a letter (unsigned) to a friend of the writer's in Holland, on the surprise of Cremona, and on French and Spanish prospects in Italy, the Netherlands, etc. The tone is one of indignation against the ambition of the King of France, which threatened the country with disgrace and defeat at the hands of the enemies be provoked, and which might cause a demand among the people for a change in Government. These sentiments are represented as being common in France. It was also considered necessary for the security of England and Holland that the House of Bourbon should cease to have any share in the monarchy of Spain, and that assurances should be given for the protection of commerce. (In French, 17 pages. Probably sent to the E of M through the agency of Martine.) Paris

Report of the Lords Commissioners of Trade to the King, setting forth the state of defence of the several "Plantations" of America as ascertained by the replies of the Governors to the enquiries of the Commissioners. It is signed by the Earl of Stamford, Sir P. Medows, Mr. Secretary Blathwayt, John Pollexfen, and Matthew Prior. (24 pages)
Copy of a letter from M. Schonenberg to Don Joseph Perez de la Puente, asking for his passports. (In Spanish) Madrid
Translation of the same into French.

Copy of a letter from the King of France to the King of Spain, congratulating the latter on the character of his consort, and on the good sense shown by both in reconciling themselves to a separation necessary to his glory [in consequence of the expedition to Italy.] Also, on the same sheet of paper, a copy of a similar letter to the Queen of Spain. (In French)
Another copy of both letters. (In French)
Copy or translation into English of a letter of Queen Anne to the King of Portugal, announcing her accession to the throne.
Draft of some instructions to Mr. Methuen, to point out to the King of Portugal the dangers of a French and the advantages of an English Alliance.
"Particulars relating to the instructions intended for Portugal," being criticisms and suggestions.

Instructions at length to Mr. Methuen, to demand of the King of Portugal free entrance into all the ports of his kingdom for the fleets of England and all her allies without restriction of number, and to return to England immediately should the demand be refused. He was also to endeavour to bring Portugal into the alliance with England, the Netherlands, and the Empire, and to offer territorial inducements for that purpose. (pp. 6) St. James
A draft of the same, with some variations.
Another draft of the same, and of the "particulars relating" to them already mentioned.
Another copy of Queen Anne's letter, announcing to the King of Portugal her accession to the throne. (See 24)
M. Hervart to Queen Anne, congratulating her upon her accession, and asking to be continued in his employment in Switzerland. (In French) Bern

Prince Eugene of Savoy to Sir Lambert Blackwell, asking for information, about deserters from his army, and promising a diary of all that passed in it. He requested Sir Lambert's good offices with respect to the letters of Don Sebastian de Villa Torres, and Don Francisco Pacho. (In Italian. On the same paper is a translation of the same into English) General Quarters at Lazzara

Translation into English of a letter from Cardinal Grimani to Cardinal Paulucci, remonstrating against the reported intention of the Pope to send a Legate to congratulate the Duc d'Anjou as King of Spain upon his arrival at Naples. This is followed by a translation of the reply of Cardinal Paulucci, to the effect that, although the Pope intended to send a legate to congratulate the King of Spain upon his arrival in Italy, no investiture had yet been granted. On the same paper are also copies of the last-mentioned two letters in Italian. Rome
Copy of a letter from the Grand Duke of Tuscany to Queen Anne, upon her accession to the Throne of England. (In Italian) Florence
Translation of the same into English.
Another copy of the last-mentioned translation.

A. Stanyan to the E of M, expressing an opinion that a projected attack of the French upon Switzerland, though postponed, was not abandoned, and that the situation might be improved to the advantage of the Allies. Bern

The Sieur J.J. Hamel Bruyninx to the E of M, expressing surprise that that certain news of the infantry destined for Catalonia having sailed had not yet been received, and a hope that Count Guido de Staremberg would prove a successful commander in place of Prince Eugene. (In French) Vienna
The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, instructing him to return to town, and prepare for immediate departure for his post [at Venice]. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 434) Whitehall

J. Chetwynd to the E of M, requesting him, when in Vienna on his way to Venice, to assist the Duke of Savoy in respect of an article of a Treaty with the Austrian Court relating to the province of Vigevenasco, in the state of Milan. Turin

The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, directing him to hasten his journey to Vienna in order to dissuade the Court there from sending troops to Naples, as that course would be destructive to the concerted design of carrying the war into Dauphiné and France. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 434) Whitehall
Robert Harley to the E of M, to the same effect, and mentioning enclosure of a memorial from M. Vryberge. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 434) Whitehall
The E of M to the Duke of Marlborough, giving an account of an interview with the Pensionary. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 435) The Hague
The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, urging haste upon the journey to Vienna, in order to prevent the intended expedition to Naples. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 437) Whitehall

G. Stepney to the E of M, warmly recommending M. Bruyninx [the Envoy of the States at Vienna] for his ability and honesty, as well as some inferior persons. (The chief part is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 436) Brussels
G. Stepney to the E of M, recommending Mr. Hicks to his notice. Brussells

The E of M to Lord Godolphin, giving an account of an interview with the Pensionary, expressing a belief that the Duke of Marlborough would "find all things well at his arrival," and touching very briefly on various points in the military and political situation. The Hague
The Electress Sophia of Hanover to the E of M, thanking him for his attachment to her House. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 436) Hanover
The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of a copy of a project concerted with the Duke of Savoy for entering France. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 439) Whitehall
M. de Robethon to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of a letter from the Elector of Hanover. Their Electoral Highnesses held the Earl in high esteem. (In French) Hanover
The Elector George Louis of Hanover to the E of M, expressing regret that the Earl had been unable to pass though Hanover. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 437) Hanover
The E of M to the Duke of Marlborough, mentioning enclosure of an important paper given to the Earl by the bearer of the letter. (Draft. Printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 437) Düsseldorf
The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, directing him to lose no time in pressing upon the Court of Vienna the matters upon which he was instructed. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 441) Whitehall

The E of M to the Duke of Marlborough, expressing hopes that the court of Vienna would at least defer the intended expedition to Naples, though they were "very fond in that matter." Fears were entertained at Vienna respecting the movements of the King of Sweden. It would be hard to satisfy the Duke of Savoy with the proceedings of the Imperial Court. (Draft.) Vienna

[The E of M] to M. de Robethon, requesting him to thank the Elector and Electress of Hanover for their letters. "A great scheme in the affairs of Europe" was now being undertaken, which it was to be hoped that the King of Sweden would not thwart. All eyes were upon the Duke of Marlborough. (Not signed. Endorsed "Not copied")

Extract from a letter from Mr. Robinson, giving an account of the reception of the Duke of Marlborough by the King of Sweden at Halle, and of the proceedings of the Duke before his departure for Berlin. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 442) Leipzig

The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, renewing instructions to dissuade the Court of Vienna from the expedition to Naples, and to persuade it, if possible, to give reasonable satisfaction to the Duke of Savoy. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 447) Whitehall
Robert Harley to the E of M, to the same effect, but insisting more particularly upon the French success in Spain as an argument to be used. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 447)

Queen Anne to the Emperor, urging upon him the importance of making a diversion by invading France, after the French success in Spain. (Copy. In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 448) Kensington
The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, instructing him that the Court of Vienna would never have the Queen's consent to their project upon Naples. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 453) Whitehall

[The E of M] to the Duke of Marlborough, informing him that the Austrian troops (about 10,000 in number) were on the march for Naples, but that the Court of Vienna promised the expedition into France should not be prejudiced in consequence. An enclosure relating to the Duke of Savoy is mentioned. Great reliance was placed upon England by the Imperial Court. They would do whatever His Grace thought was for the common good. The Earl would send the patterns for "my Lady Duchess." (Signature wanting. Paper torn)

Undirected letter from Count Ardizzoni, Minister of State of the Duke of Mantua, complaining that the Duke was kept out of possession of Montferrat and other fiefs dependent on the Holy Roman Empire. (In Latin. Copy. Endorsed "Sent by Broughton unto the Earl of Sunderland at the instance of the Duke of Mantua." A translation, headed "to the Earl of Sunderland," is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 446) Venice

The E of M to the Lord Treasurer (Lord Godolphin), expressing doubts whether the Imperial Court would aid the invasion of France, and giving some particulars of the European situation as affecting Italy, Sweden, Poland, Hungary, etc. (Copy. Printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 452)
Le Sieur J.J. Hamel Bruyninx to the E of M, mentioning an enclosure received from the Prince of Salm, apparently on the subject of the Naples expedition. (In French)

The E of M to the Duke of Marlborough, mentioning an enclosure which related to the affairs of the Duke of Savoy and another enclosure which was an extract from a letter from the Prince of Salm, and describing the relations of Sweden with the Emperor. (Copy. Reference is made to this letter, though it is not printed, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 453) Vienna
The Duke of Marlborough to the E of M, to the effect that he intended to join the army at Halle, and there was a prospect of a battle. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 448) Brussels

Count Tarin to the E of M, regretting that he had had no better success than the Earl in his diplomacy at the Court of Vienna, and requesting the Earl to confer with the Marquis de Prié. (In French) Vienna
The Duke of Marlborough to the E of M, expressing his desire to give battle to the enemy, in order to repair the misfortune in Spain. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 453) Camp at Lembecq

H. Boyle to the E of M, to the effect that the French had 90,000 men in Flanders, and that the Queen was detained in town by the excess of business connected with the Union. As Bonincini could not be "got over" to England, it would be necessary to be content with having his music, especially his new opera. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne." ii., 223) London

Robert Sutton to the E of M, on the relations of the Port and the Tartars with the Empire and with Muscovy, and on the probable maintenance of peace by Turkey for at least a year. (Printed, Cole's Memoirs, p. 436) Pera of Constantinople

James Cressett to the E of M, to the effect that the Electress of Hanover considered the Earl to be one of her friends, and would receive a letter from him with pleasure. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 395) Hanover
The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, informing him of the Queen's desire that the Duke of Savoy should obtain satisfaction at the Court of Vienna. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 459) Whitehall

Robert Sutton to the E of M, describing a serious conspiracy to depose the Sultan, and stating that the French had sent nearly 200,000 dollars to the Hungarian malecontents. (Printed, almost in full, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 461) Pera of Constantinople

The E of M to the Lord Treasurer (Lord Godolphin), giving a description of the character of the Duke of Savoy, and of the political situation as affected by the age and health of the Emperor, his wife, and King Charles, and by the expedition to Naples. (Draft, with many interlineations and alterations.) Venice
The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, assuring him of the Queen's continued support of the Duke of Savoy. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 462) Whitehall
Joseph Addison to the E of M, sending a copy of a short letter from Lisbon on the affairs in the peninsula. Whitehall
J. Vanbrugh to the E of M, giving a description of an enclosed design for restorations at Kimbolton, etc. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii. 227) London

J. Chetwynd to the E of M, announcing that the land forces were within four marches of Toulon, and that Sir Cloudesly Shovell had appeared off the Isle of Hiéres. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 461) Camp at Frejus.

Lord Halifax to the E of M, expressing thanks for a Cantata of the Emperor's own composition, as well as other musical works, and an opinion that the Emperor would excel his predecessor in music more than in politics. The Cantata was so good that Bonincini might be suspected to have "had a hand in it." Blackall would not be made Bishop of Exeter, but Dawes would be made Bishop of Chester, and Dr. Trimnel, Bishop of Norwich. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii. 231)
M. Boury to the E of M, to the effect that there was nothing new to report of the armies of the Netherlands. (In French) The Hague

The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, expressing fears that the Emperor would not, after his success in Naples, aid in the expedition against France, but would adhere to the practice of "riding a new acquired country with German garrisons." (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 466) Whitehall
C. Godolphin to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of a memorial relating to claims of the Godolphin family in the Venetian lawcourts, and giving explanations. (Signed only by C. Godolphin) London
The same letter, written and signed by C. Godolphin. London

Lord Raby to the E of M, to the effect that there was uncertainty respecting the designs of the King of Sweden, and that the position of the Imperial army was improved. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 463) Berlin

Le Sieur J.J. Hamel Bruyninx to the E of M, lamenting the inaction in the Netherlands, and expressing his opinion that the Imperial movements would be too late, and that to attempt to make anything better of a German was as hopeless a task as to wash a black-a- moor white. (In French) Vienna
Sir Cloudesley Shovell to the E of M, giving some details of the preparations for an attack upon Toulon, but expressing doubts of the result. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 467) Fleet before Hiéres

A. Stanyan to the E of M, giving a description of the Tribunal for settling the claim of the King of Prussia to Neufchâtel, and expressing his belief "that the weighty arguments of religion and liberty will turn the scale in our favour if we pay as much for justice as any of our competitors." Some details of the forces for the invasion of France are added. Six pages, of which the first four are printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 463) Neufchâtel
Sir James Montague [Montagu] to the E of M, giving an account of the proceedings in Parliament after the Union, with some family and other gossip. (Endorsed "Baron Mountague") London
Sir James Montague [Montagu] to the E of M, to introduce the son of Sir Francis Child. (Endorsed "Baron Mountague") London
J. Chetwynd to the E of M, complaining that "things did not go as they ought to do" before Toulon. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 465) Camp at La Vallette

J. Chetwynd to the E of M, giving an account of the sortie of the French from Toulon, and of subsequent military movements, and concluding with the news that "the Allies were to steal away as they could." (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 470. The beginning is in the form of a journal said, in Cole's Memoirs, to have been sent to Mr. Cole.) Camp at La Vallette

The Duke of Marlborough to the E of M, mentioning that (according to a letter from Mr. Robinson) a conference had been held, at the desire of Count Wratislaw, between Count Piper and the Dutch minister. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 465) Camp at Meldert

The E of M to Lord Godolphin, requesting the presentation of a letter to the Queen "in relation to passing a Privy Seal for the Plate" the Earl had had of the Crown, as he had now served on three embassies with it. (Draft) Venice

J. D'Alais to the E of M, announcing that the Elector of Hanover would have his preparations for the expedition to the Rhine completed at the end of the month. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 367) Hanover

The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, instructing the latter to ascertain whether the Venetians would be willing to join the Allies and furnish troops if the Imperial garrison were withdrawn from Mantua. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 469) Whitehall

A. Stanyan to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of a memorial on the subject of the conflicting claims to Neufchâtel, and some information received concerning the position at Toulon. (Printed, in part, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 468) Neufchâtel.

Lord Cowper to the E of M, speculating on the probable issue of the attack on Toulon, about which public feeling was uneasy. Should it succeed, he says, "I apprehend through the transport of joy, or the effect of it here, where good fellowship is in fashion, we should be in danger of losing no small number of honest men in the cause at home." Herlingfordbury

Sir John Norris to the E of M, announcing the retreat of the Allied army and the departure of the fleet from before Toulon. He had always "had a doubt if a certain man was earnestly desirous of this expedition." He would, if he had the opportunity, give the Earl verbally his "real opinion on that matter, and the present misfortune." On board the Torbay before Toulon
J. Addison to the E of M, touching very briefly on various topics. (Printed, almost in full, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 472) Whitehall

Sir P. Medows to the E of M, to the effect that orders had been sent to Count Martinitz to permit the Duke of Savoy to draw out "what number [of troops] he judged reasonable." M. Mellarede had been at Vienna since the Earl left, and was not less dissatisfied. The Austrians were making merry at the past attempts to dissuade them from the Naples expedition, which alone had been successful. The fate of Europe was like to turn on the good behaviour, conduct, and success of his Royal Highness. Vienna

Lord Godolphin to the E of M, instructing him to take the first opportunity of proposing to the Republic of Venice to enter into the Grand Alliance, and support the Allies with 10,000 or 12,000 men, and mentioning the terms which were to be offered: viz., the troops to be commanded by a General of their own, a subsidy to be allowed, and peace not to be made without notice to the Venetians, and their participation in it. Windsor

E. Lewis to the E of M. Lord Peterborough had been ordered to "prepare a relation in writing of what he had done abroad in execution of his commission." Mr. Scott, one of the Chamberlains at Hanover, had been "intriguing to promote the invitation," but had been disavowed by the Elector. It was expected that the Duke of Devonshire would "have his Father's staff [as Lord High Steward], and that the E of M would have his Guards again. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii., 244) Whitehall

J. Addison to the E of M, touching very briefly on various topics. It was hoped that the Duke of Marlborough would "set all things right again, as he had done formerly when affairs were in a more desperate posture." (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii., 245) Whitehall

J. Addison to the E of M, mentioning advices from Lisbon to the effect that the French had not followed up their victory at Almanza, and had allowed their adversaries time to recover. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 475) Whitehall

The Duke of Somerset to the E of M. The Duke of Devonshire was dead. Lady E. Savage, old as she was, had married young St. John Manwaring. The Queen was going to Newmarket about the end of September, and the Prince was better and might be able to go there also. Syon
