A. Stanyan to the E of M, describing the growing warmth of the dispute between the Prince de Conti and the Prussian Ambassador for precedence. (The principal part is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 469) Neufchâtel

Sir. P. Meadows [Medows] to the E of M, giving some particulars of "Count Wratislaw's affair," expressing apprehensions of the progress of the French arms, and mentioning a remittance of 200,000 dollars from France for the service of the Hungarians. (Printed, in part, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 472) Vienna
Sir Cloudesley Shovell to the E of M, announcing that the siege of Toulon had been raised, and that the allied army had decamped. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 471) Association, before Toulon

A. Stanyan to the E of M to the effect that the hearing of the claims to Neufchâtel had been deferred by the Tribunal at the instance of the Prince de Conti. (The principal part is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 474) Neufchâtel
Sir P. Medows to the E of M, expressing fears that the King of Sweden intended mischief to the Allies. (Printed, in part, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 474) Vienna
Henry Newton to the E of M, complaining of the oppression of the Italians by the Germans, and giving news from Naples to Sep. 6, from Toulon to Aug. 25, and from Genoa to Sep. 10. Florence
Lord Raby to the E of M, announcing that the King of Sweden had come to an agreement with the Emperor. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 476) Berlin
A. Stanyan to the E of M, giving an account of the preliminary proceedings of the Tribunal for deciding upon the claims to Neufchâtel. (Printed, almost in full, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 476) Neufchâtel
J. Vanbrugh to the E of M on the plans for re-building at Kimbolton, etc. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii., 250) London
Sir P. Medows to the E of M, announcing that the Treaty with the king of Sweden had been despatched, etc. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 447) Vienna
J. Chetwynd to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of a journal containing an account of the retreat from Toulon. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 447) Salusse
A. Stanyan to the E of M, on the proceedings of the Tribunal for for trying the claims to Neufchâtel. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 478) Neufchâtel
A. Stanyan to the E of M, chiefly on the same subject. (Printed, almost in full, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 480) Neufchâtel
J. Addison to some person addressed as "Sir," announcing the death of Mr. Stepney. (Printed, as having been addressed to Mr. Cole, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 481)

The E of M to the Lord Treasurer (Lord Godolphin), on the improbability that the Venetian Republic would be induced to join the Grand Alliance after the failure of the attack on Toulon. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 479) Venice

J. Chetwynd to the E of M, attributing the mishap at Toulon to the indolence and ill-will of some of the Generals of the Allies, and announcing that an attempt was to be made upon Susa and La Perouse. (Printed, almost in full, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 479) Camp at Scalin

Sir P. Medows to the E of M. It was said that King Charles [III, of Spain] was about to be married. The Venetians were "willing to withdraw their offer," which the Austrian Court had "never embraced." The Savoy Ministers," too, had been alarmed at it, and it was feared that His Royal Highness was soured by the delay in granting him the investitures desired by him. Vienna
The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, instructing him to continue his efforts to bring the Venetians into the Grand Alliance. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 483) Whitehall

A. Cardonnel [Secretary to the Duke of Marlborough] to Mr. Cole, complaining of the conduct of the Germans, and adding "God preserve us hereafter from such allies." (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 482) Camp at Helchin

J. Addison to the E of M, to the effect that great damage had been done to Toulon by the bombardment before the fleet withdrew, and the French had sunk twenty of their own ships to save them from burning. Lord Peterborough had been ordered to give in his accounts by the following Sunday, and be examined by the Committee of Lords. Whitehall
J. Addison to Mr. Cole, mentioning enclosure of a letter from the Bishop of Salisbury to Erizzo (which the Bishop wished Mr. Cole to superscribe), and giving some particulars of Mr. Stepney's will.

A. Stanyan to the E of M, to the effect that the King of Prussia would probably be declared Prince of Neufchâtel, after the withdrawal, under protest, of the other Pretenders. (Printed, almost in full, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 483) Neufchâtel
Journal (endorsed J. Chetwynd, esq.) of events including the fall of Susa, etc. (A portion is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 484) Turin

J. Addison to [the E of M?], describing a debate in the House of Commons on the question of continuing the Privy Council in Scotland. "The Scotch members were divided, and spoke very largely and they say well on each side, the rest of the House remaining silent for two hours and giving an obliging attention to their new brethren."

Signor Cornaro to the E of M, expressing hopes that the Earl would enjoy his sojourn at Venice, especially during the carnival, mentioning an opera sent by the Earl from Vienna, and recommending the music of Mendicanti and Biffi. (In French) Newmarket

M. Boury to the E of M, informing him that the Duke [of Marlborough] was passing a few hours at the Hague before rejoining the army. He would afterwards proceed to Frankfurt to concert measures with the Electors of Hanover and Mayence. (In French) The Hague

J. Addison to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of a project of a commercial treaty with the Republic of Venice, and giving some items of Home news. (Printed, in part, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 487) Cockpit

Henry Newton to the E o f M, expressing doubts whether the Court of Florence could be persuaded to join the Allies, unless the fall of Gaeta caused some change of policy. The garrison of Gaeta (officers and soldiers) had been put to the sword. Florence

J. Chetwynd to the E of M, to the effect that there were some hopes that the Duke of Savoy and Prince Eugene might make the winter quarters of the troops under them in Savoy and on the frontier of Dauphiné. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 484)
J. Chetwynd to the E of M, giving the news from various parts of Italy. (A part is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 485) Turin

The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, to the effect that efforts should still be made to bring the Venetians into the Grand Alliance, and that the differences between the Duke of Savoy and Prince Eugene were to be deplored. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 492) Whitehall

A. Stanyan to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of a copy of a French Memorial, which charged partiality against the Tribunal for deciding the claims on Neufchâtel, and made certain demands, etc. (Printed, almost in full, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 486) Neufchâtel

Sir P. Medows to the E of M, to the effect that the Court of Vienna was not pleased with the suggestion that Mantua should be garrisoned with troops in English and Dutch pay, as an inducement to the Venetians to join the Grand Alliance. (Printed, almost in full, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 486) Vienna

J. Chetwynd to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of Proceedings of the Council at which it was decided that the troops should not take up winter quarters in Savoy, etc. (Printed, in part, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 492) Turin

A. Stanyan to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of a second Memorial from the French Ambassador, and giving other details respecting the proceedings in relation to the claims to Neufchâtel. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 491) Neufchâtel

Sir P. Medows to the E of M, announcing that the investitures long withheld were about to be granted to the Duke of Savoy by the Emperor, etc. (Printed, almost in full, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 492) Vienna

Robert Sutton to the E of M, to the effect that there was no reason to suppose the Turks had any design against the Republic of Venice, but that they were favouring the Hungarian malecontents of the Empire. Some particulars relating to the Church in Armenia are added. (Pp. 5. The principal part is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 492) Pera of Constantinople

J. Addison to the E of M, giving an account of various naval disasters, including the loss of Sir Cloudesley Shovell. He adds: "There is that noble spirit in the nation and our new British Parliament that, I hope, will surmount all difficulties." (Printed in Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii., 259) Cockpit

A. Stanyan to the E of M, expressing a belief that the "Three States" would give the King of Prussia the investiture of Neufchâtel on the 3rd and 4th of November. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 494) Neufchâtel
The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, informing him that the draft treaty of commerce would be finished in a few days. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 495) Whitehall
J. Addison to Mr. Cole, describing the finding of the body of Sir Cloudesley Shovell on the coast of Cornwall. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 496) Cockpit
The E of M to the Lord Treasurer (Lord Godolphin), respecting the payment of his allowance. (Draft) Venice
A. Stanyan to the E of M, annoncing the decision of the Swiss Tribunal in favour of the claim of the King of Prussia to Neufchâtel. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 494)

Sir P. Medows to the E of M. He wondered at the conduct of the Venetian Ambassador at Vienna, who was raising a great "stir and to-do about the proposition made a considerable while ago by order from Whitehall." The Prince of Salms had been preferred to Cardinal Lemberg. This was disagreeable to the "first favourite the Grand Veueur," who by way of compensation had been declared a Prince of the Empire, and had gone beyond Baden to prepare a bear-hunt for the Emperor. Count Wratislaw had arrived at Frankfurt, and proceeded thence to the Hague with the Duke of Marlborough. Vienna

The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, informing him of the Queen's approval of every step he had taken, and assuring him that Parliament desired to prosecute the war with the utmost vigor. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 498) Whitehall

A. Stanyan to the E of M, mentioning enclosure af a copy of the Sentence by which the Investiture of the Counties of Neufchâtel and Vallangin was granted to the King of Prussia. (Printed, almost in full, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 495) Neufchâtel

Sir James Montague [Montagu] to the E of M, partly on family business, but partly on the question whether the Earl should accept the office offered to him on his return. Reference is also made to the discussion whether the Parliament was new or old, which was "compromised by agreeing to part with such officers as were declared incapable to sit and vote in any Parliament which should be holden from and after the determination of the last."

E. L. (endorsed Mr. Lewis) to [Mr. Cole?], to the effect that the Parliament had been "voted new" (with a reservation in favour of certain office-holders, and that "My Lord might have the Yeomen of the Guard," as a matter of course. (Incomplete.) Whitehall

Sir P. Medows to the E of M. "The face of our affair is not so fair." The Duke of Mantua would probably not be put to the Ban of the Empire, and "H.R.H." [the Duke of Savoy] would not "infallibly succeed." Medows had been with the Court to the bear-hunt, but he would rather "go out of his way to avoid such a creature than to travel thirty miles to pursue it." Vienna

J. Chetwynd to the E of M, expressing his belief that the Court of Vienna had terminated matters to the satisfaction of "H.R.H." [the Duke of Savoy] in all except the equivalent for the Vigevanesco. The investiture for Montferrat, however, was not quite as H.R.H. desired, since the Ban had not been published against the Duke of Mantua. There had been a delay in the embarcation, but it was hoped that all the troops would have sailed before the end of the month. Turin

A. Stanyan to the E of M. The Catholic Cantons were disinclined to acknowledge the award of Neufchâtel to the King of Prussia, and France had "published a prohibition of commerce." Mr. Stanyan's return to Bern was delayed because "Count Metternich had desired the Dutch minister" and Mr. Stanyan "to sign some accounts of money which had been laid out for his master's service during the negotiation, and distributed by our approbation." Neufchâtel
J. Chetwynd to the E of M, giving particulars (derived from letters) of military movements, etc. Turin

James Dayrolle to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of a journal, and expressing an opinion that the Dutch would be willing to continue the war, if they could support the expense, and saw "England earnest upon the matter." The Hague

J. Chetwynd to the E of M, expressing fears that there was no prospect of a successful campaign in his neighborhood, and that the Duke of Savoy would be glad to see the the war at an end. (Printed, almost in full, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 499) Turin
Sir P. Medows to the E of M, on various proceedings and rumours at the Court of Vienna. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 499) Vienna
The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, acknowledging receipt of a Memorial of the Venetian Senate, etc. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 504) Whitehall
Memorandum [from Mr. Chetwynd] to the E of M, giving particulars of naval and military movements, etc., as made known to him by various correspondence. Turin
J. Chetwynd to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of the above memorandum. Chetwynd had heard from "H.R.H." that he was to be recalled, and prayed the Earl's protection. Turin

A. Stanyan to the E of M, on a threatened invasion of Neufchâtel by the French, on the willingness of the Protestant cantons to aid in its defence, and on the probability that a treaty of neutrality for it would be arranged. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 502) Bern
[Major-General] William Cadogan to the E of M, announcing his appointment as Ambassador Extraordinary to the United Provinces. (Printed, in part, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 503) Brussels
Christopher Crowe to the E of M, to the effect that every effort would be made to apprehend seamen who had deserted. Leghorn
A. Stanyan to the E of M, again expressing a belief that there would be a treaty of neutrality between France and Neufchâtel. (Printed, almost in full, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 504) Bern
The Duke of Modena to the E of M. Letter to serve as a credential to the Abbate Giardani. (In Italian) Modena

J. Addison to the E of M, describing some Parliamentary proceedings, but chiefly the consideration in the House of Lords, of the case of Lord Peterborough and the expedition conducted by him. "Public business never went on better." Cockpit
Henry Newton to the E of M, announcing the death of Admiral Dilks, at Leghorn, etc. Florence

William Chetwynd to the E of M, announcing that his brother had gone to Genoa to facilitate the embarcation of troops for Spain, and mentioning two enclosures received from Mr. Stanyan. Nothing more had been heard touching his brother's recall. Turin

The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, expressing a hope that the Address (described as being enclosed) of both Houses to the Queen would remove any impression that England was disposed towards peace. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 508) Whitehall
J. Addison to the E of M, giving an account of a debate in the House of Lords on the conduct of the war.

William Chetwynd to the E of M, announcing that transports had sailed from Genoa to Vado, for the embarcation of troops for Spain. An attempt upon Sardinia now seemed probable. Orbitello and San Stefano had declared for King Charles. The delays of the Court of Vienna might drive H.R.H. to a "rash resolution" of which he was by no means incapable. Turin

J. Dayrolle to the E of M, informing him that the Dutch were convinced of the necessity of continuing the war until "the French generation was removed from Spain." (The principal part is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 507) The Hague

A. Stanyan to the E of M, expressing his belief that the French Ambassador had concealed from the French Court the offer of neutrality for Neufchâtel made by the King of Prussia, and giving some particulars of the situation. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 507) Bern
C. Godolphin to the E of M, giving a summary of the proceedings in his case at Venice, and praying the Earl's protection. London
J. Chetwynd to the Earl of Sunderland, giving minute details of the preparations for the proposed expedition to Spain, an estimate of the French force at sea, etc. (Copy. Four large pages) Savona
E. Howe to the E of M, announcing his return to Hanover, and mentioning an enclosure. Hanover

J. Chetwynd to the Earl of Sunderland, giving various particulars of the expedition to Catalonia, and expressing grave apprehensions of the result of the decision of the naval commanders to make for Lisbon rather than remain in the Mediterranean after the landing of the troops. This is followed by what appears to be a letter from Chetwynd to the Naval commanders, suggesting their return to Italy after landing the troops in Catalonia. (Copies. Four large pages in all) Bay of Vado

William Chetwynd to the E of M, announcing that the whole of the troops destined for Spain had embarked, though both officers and men had shown unwillingness. The Governor of La Perouse had been defeated by the Vaudois. The Marquis de Constance, Envoy of H.R.H. to Vienna was about to set out. An enclosure from Mr. Stanyan is mentioned. Turin
Memorandum on the subject of the recognition of the King of Prussia by the Republic of Venice. (In French) Westminster

Extract from a Declaration made on behalf of the Emperor to Count Tarino, regretting that mischances had prevented the payment of debts to the Duke of Savoy, and making promises for the future. (In French) Vienna

Memorial of M. Van Vryberge, the Dutch Envoy in England, communicating to Queen Anne the instructions given to the Dutch Envoy Extraordinary in Vienna to represent the Imperial Court to the advantages of an attack upon France rather than upon Naples. (In French) London
Answer of Count Zinzendorf to the Memorial presented to the Emperor by General Doppf, the Dutch Envoy, on the conduct of the war. (In French) Vienna
Memorandum, relating to the Vigevanesco. (In French)
Another memorandum, relating to the Vigevanesco, almost identical with the last.

Count Piper to Count Zinzendorf, communicating a Memorial [from the King of Sweden] on the subject of Muscovite troops which had passed from Saxony into the Swedish camp. The memorial follows. (Copies. The letter in French, the Memorial in Latin) Alt Ranstatt

Statement, relating to the Vigevanesco and the claims of the Duke of Savoy. (In French. Endorsed, "E of M's Memorial with the Answer." The document, however, is the answer without the Memorial, which is at the end of the present volume (32). Translations of both are printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 449)
"Memorial of Articles presented to Sir Charles Hedges, Her Majesty's Principal Secretary of State, for the improvement of our trade to Venice."
Another copy of the same.
Memorandum, on the subject of the Vigevanesco and the claims of the Duke of Savoy. (In French)
Memorial of the Elector Palatine to the Emperor, embodying certain claims, and giving a historical retrospect. (In French. Copy. pp. 6)
Copy of a protest of the Duke of Savoy on the subject of the Vigevanesco. (In Italian) Turin
Project presented to the Emperor for the regulation of the new free port to be opened at Buccari. (In Italian. pp. 6)

Memorial of J.J. Hamel Bruyninx, Dutch Envoy at Vienna, urging the importance of the allied expedition against France as compared with the Imperial expedition to Naples. (In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 441)
Remonstrances and defence of the Imperial Court, in relation to the campaign in Italy, with reference to the Fifth Article of the Grand Alliance. (In French. Copy. Ten pages)
Francesco Maria Ottieri to the E of M, giving the news which had reached him from various quarters. (In Italian) Rome
Confirmation of the treaty of Osnaburg by the King of Sweden. (In Latin. Copy.) Camp at Trancovic

Note of a wager between Robert Davis and Pietro Bernard, the one betting that Toulon would be in the hands of the Allies in October, the other that it would remain in the hands of the French. (In Italian) Venice
Memorandum, relating to the embarcation of the allied troops to be sent from Italy to Spain, and to the difficulties attending it. (In French. Copy.) Turin

Extract from the Register of the "Trois Etats" being the award of Neufchâtel and Valangin to the King of Prussia. (In French. Endorsed, "Extrait du Registre des trois Estauts, etc, concernant Orange")
The E of M to [Count Tarin, Tarini, or Tarino?], on the affairs of the Duke of Savoy. (Draft. In French. Endorsed, "Lord Manchester's letter after his arrival at Venice." Venice
Copy of a report (transmitted apparently to the E of M) of Erizzo and Pisani to the Venetian Government, on their return from their Embassy to England. (In Italian) Venice
Extract, relating to proceedings of the "Trois Etats," touching the affairs of Neufchâtel. (In French)
Unsigned note to the E of M, agreeing to his proposal of a verbal discussion on the subject of a proposed treaty of commerce. (In Italian) [Venice]

Unsigned Memorial (of the E of M apparently) to the Doge of Venice, urging the advantages to the Republic of joining the Allies, and pointing out the dangers of isolation. (In Italian. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 497, where the date assigned is Nov. 15, 1707) Venice

Memorial of the E of M to the Doge of Venice, urging the advantages to the Republic of joining the Grand Alliance, and stating the terms on which Venice might accede to it. (In Italian. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 489) Venice
Note by the E of M of the sum remaining due to him on account of his Embassy to Venice.
Sonnet (by Aurelio Aurlei) to the E of M, on the occasion of his going to hear the opera "Igene, Regina di Sparta," at Vicenza. (in Italian. Printed.)

V. C. to her "Sovrano Signor" [the E of M?], assuring him that her heart had been "privo di consolatione," since he had left Venice, and she found herself separated from "un si beneficio Protetore," etc. Her only wish in life was to be his most humble and ready slave, unchangeably until death. (In Italian)
Draft of treaty of commerce between Queen Anne and the Republic of Venice.

Memorial of the E of M to the Emperor, on the claims of the Duke of Savoy. (Copy. In French. A translation is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 449, together with a translation of the Answer, a copy of which in French is bound in the present volume, ante 8.)

The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, recommending to the protection of the latter the affairs of Mr. Carre, whose ship, the "Joseph Gally," had been seized by the French in Venetian waters. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 509) Whitehall

J. Chetwynd to the E of M, mentioning enclosures of copies of letters to the Earl of Sunderland, which contained a full account of transactions relating to the succours to Spain from Italy. Mr. Chetwynd now hoped that he would not be re-called. Turin
Sir P. Medows to the E of M, giving various items of news from Vienna. (The principal part is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 508) Vienna

A. Stanyan to the E of M, expressing doubts of the intentions of the French with respect to Neufchâtel, and announcing that they had concentrated 12,000 men on the frontiers, to be commanded by Marshal Villars. Bern
Count Comazzi's statement, relating to the causes of his imprisonment (which he attributed to the E of M), and prayer to have his Memorial submitted to the Prince of Salms. (In Italian) Neusdorf

A. Stanyan to the E of M, announcing that 10,000 troops had been sent to the frontier of Franch-Comté to defend Neufchâtel, and expressing hopes that the French would agree to a Treaty of Neutrality. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 509) Bern.
J. Addison to the E of M, on the discussion of Lord Peterborough's expedition in the House of the Lords. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 269) Bern
The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of a draft treaty of commerce. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 510) Whitehall

A. Stanyan to the E of M, describing the offer of the French King to let Neufchâtel remain in a perfect neutrality, if the Cantons would engage to keep the territory in sequestration till a general peace was made. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 510) Bern

J. Addison to the E of M, describing debates in the House of Commons upon the Recruiting Bill, and upon Ways and Means. The Bill for abolishing the Privy Council, and establishing Justices of the Peace, in Scotland had passed. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 273) Bern
A. Stanyan to the E of M, expressing an opinion that the Cantons would not agree to the scheme for the sequestration of Neufchâtel. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 511) Bern
J. Addison to the E of M, on proceedings in Parliament, especially on the case of Commodore Kerr in the House of Lords.

Lord Raby to the E of M, to the effect that there need be no doubt on the subject of the "8,000 men," as the King of Prussia was well disposed to Her Majesty. The Venetians were not worthy of much consideration, but would, perhaps, be more tractable when the Swiss were drawn into an offensive war against France, as they probably would be before they were "well aware of it." Berlin

The Earl of Galway to the E of M, announcing the arrival of a part of the forces from Italy, and expressing apprehensions of delay in the transport of the rest. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 512) Barcelona

Sir P. Medows to the E of M, describing proposals of the Imperial Court for the despatch of reinforcements to Spain, and the position of the Duke of Savoy's affairs. The French had been "Contriving to get Fribourg into their hands, and 100,000 livres was the price set, but the commander, a Swiss, was too honest for them, and gave General Thungen notice from time to time, so that if they had proceeded to put their design in execution, the 22nd of the last month they had cost the Imperialists powder and ball." Vienna

A. Stanyan to the E of M, to the effect that the issue of the deliberations of the Diet, and the real designs of the French respecting Neufchâtel were still in uncertainty. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 512) Bern

J. Addison to the E of M, giving the numbers in the division in the House of Lords on the dissolution of the Scotch Privy Council. "This day," he adds, "being the Queen's birthday, there has been a great appearance at Kensington, and will be a greater this evening. Her Majesty did not come to town, and has not ordered any ball or comedy," which they say will be reserved for H.R.H.'s birthday. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 275) Cockpit

S. Edwin to the E of M, on the state of parties, the Court, the proceedings in the House of Lords relating to the Scotch Privy Council and Lord Peterborough, etc. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 270) Exchequer

J. Addison to the E of M, confiding to him the dismissal of Mr. Secretary Harley, and the appointment of a committee of Lords to examine Gregg, and "other State criminals," especially Valiere, who, having been employed by Harley as "an owler," had carried on a secret correspondence between the French Court and some of their friends in this country. The final debate in the House of Lords on the abolition of the Scotch Privy Council is also described. Mr. Boyle was to succeed Harley, and would be succeeded at the treasury by the Speaker. (Printed, without date, in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 278)
J. Chetwynd to the E of M, mentioning the enthusiasm excited at Turin by a picture of Queen Anne, announcing his re-call, and asking for the Earl's interest and protection. Turin
A. Stanyan to the E of M, on proceedings related to the proposed neutrality of Neufchâtel. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 513) Bern

J. Addison to the E of M, announcing the appointment of Mr. Boyle as Secretary, and mentioning various rumours of other appointments. "It is said Mr. Harley and his friends had laid scheme to undermine most of our great officers of the State, and plant their own party in the room of 'em. If we may believe common fame, he himself was to have been a peer and Lord Treasurer... It is, I believe, very certain that the Duke of Marlborough and Lord Treasurer refused to sit any longer in council with so wily a Secretary, and would have laid down themselves, if he had not been removed. It is said he had hopes of working his ends by the assistance of a Bed-chamber woman, whom, it seems, he has found out to be his cousin." (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 280)

Sir James Montague [Montagu] to the E of M, on family matters, and on the recent changes of office, the dismissal of Mr. Harley, "for setting up a faction against my Lord Duke of Marlborough and Lord Treasurer," his own expected promotion to be Attorney-General, etc. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne, ii, 282)

The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, instructing him to press the treaty of commerce upon the Venetians, and to give no encouragement to the Duke of Mantua. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 515) Whitehall
J. Chetwynd to the E of M, announcing that he expected to be succeeded by Mr. Palmes, and giving some particulars relative to the Duke of Savoy. Turin
A. Stanyan to the E of M, on the prospects of arranging a neutrality for Neufchâtel. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 513) Bern
J. Addison to the E of M, on various proceedings in the House of Lords and Commons. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 284)
J. Vanbrugh to the E of M, on the opera in London. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 289) London
J. Addison to the E of M, on the opera, and on debates in the Commons. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 291)

J. Chetwynd to the E of M, announcing that the investiture of Montferrat, etc, had been conceded to the Duke of Savoy by the Court of Vienna, but that it was unlikely he would succeed in obtaining the Novaresse in compensation for money advanced on the Emperor's account. Some details respecting the movements of the fleet are added, with an unfavourable opinion of the expedition to Spain. Turin

Sir P. Medows to the E of M, chiefly upon the terms upon which the Court of Vienna was willing to grant investiture of the Palatinate, etc. Count Staremberg's luggage was on its was to Italy. The Duke of Marlborough, it was expected, would meet Prince Eugene at Hanover "for their concerting measures." At Ratisbon it had been agreed to borrow 1,000,000 crowns and to take 3,000 Saxons into the service of the Empire. Vienna
A. Stanyan to the E of M, on various aspects of the Neufchâtel affair. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 515) Berne [Bern]
J. Addison to the E of M. "This day the Committee of Lords make report of their examination of the State Criminals..." Cockpit

J. Addison to the E of M, on Parliamentary business and on the great naval preparations made by Great Britain against the expected French invasion in the interests of the Pretender. The Postscript only is in Addison's hand: "My eyes being out of order, I am forced to make use of another hand." (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 296)

The E of M to the Lord Treasurer, expressing his belief that little good was to be effected at Venice, and that the alliance of the Venetians was of little worth, could it even be obtained. Affairs at Vienna were managed by Cardinal Lambert, Prince Eugene, and Count Wratislaw. The Prince would not go to Spain, but would meet the Duke of Marlborough at the Hague. The chief hope of the allies must be fixed upon his Grace. The Earl expresses his thanks for the Privy Seal giving him his plate, and calls attention to the sum due to him from the Treasury. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 298) Venice
Speech of the E of M [apparently to the Doge of Venice.] (Printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 481, where the probably correct date assigned is Sep. 22, 1707)

The E of M to the Duke of Montagu, acquainting him with the arrival of Lord Hinchinbrook at Venice, and offering suggestions respecting the future movements of the young man who had more life and spirit than powers of application, and who had recently had a difference with M. La Come, which had been accommodated by the Earl. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 309) Venice

J. Chetwynd to the E of M, thanking the Earl for his protection and advice. Marshal Staremberg was, according to advices from Vienna, "the person designed for Spain," whither more Imperial troops would be sent. It was, however to be feared the Duke of Orleans would make his footing in Spain so good that it would be no easy matter to dislodge him. An enclosure relating to the affairs of Savoy is mentioned. Turin
A. Stanyan to the E of M, on various matters relating to the proposed neutrality of Neufchâtel. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 516) Berne [Bern]
J. Addison to the E of M, on proceedings in Parliament.

Sir P. Medows to the E of M, chiefly on the proceedings at a meeting of the states of Hungary at Pressburg. Some arrivals at Vienna, and some appointments to the Imperial army in Catalonia are noticed, as well as some acts of violence committed by Hungarian malcontents. Vienna
A. Stanyan to the E of M, on matters relating to Neufchâtel. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 517) Berne [Bern]
J. Addison to [the E of M] on proceedings in Parliament.
J. Addison to [the E of M] on proceedings in Parliament. Cockpit
J. Addison to [the E of M] on proceedings in Parliament. Cockpit

The E of M to the Duchess of Marlborough, recommending a Venetian musician to the notice of the Duchess, and of the Queen. (Draft. Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 321) Venice

Letter (unsigned and unaddressed) containing an account of a circular letter of the King of France, on the occasion of the projected invasion of Scotland, and some particulars of the expedition, and of the Pretender's movements. (In French. See A. Stanyan to the E of M, 50) Geneva
Henry Newton to the E of M, to the effect that he had little news to mention except the arrival of a ship from Turkey, which had been captured by a Zealand privateer. Leghorn

J. Vanbrugh to the E of M, regretting that Great Britain had trusted too much her navy, and that there were no land forces in Scotland to meet the projected invasion. The news that Admiral Byng was in sight of the French fleet, however, led to the belief that no landing would be effected. The Duke of Marlborough had letters from Paris to the effect that "this project was opinionated by the King of France, against the opinion of others; which would incline one to think if it did not succeed one way he wished it would another, by getting rid of the Pretender, which is likely enough to happen." There is also some discussion of operatic matters. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 318) London
John Scudamore to the E of M, on damask velvets wanted by the Duchess of Marlborough, and the price of marble chimney-pieces. The English fleet at Gibraltar was short of provisions. Genoa

A. Stanyan to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of a letter from Geneva, which purported to give an account of the French project for the invasion of Scotland. (See 46. The greater part of the letter, but without the enclosure, is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 518) Bern

Sir P. Medows to the E of M, on the Emperor's approval of the Resolution of the Diet, the religious affairs of the Empire, the proceedings of the Hungarian malecontents, the departure of Prince Eugene for Holland, the proposal that England should transport 6,000 Germans from Italy to Catalonia at her own expense, the insufficiency of the forces supplied by the Emperor, and the proposal to make Bucari a free port. (pp. 7) Vienna
J. Vanbrugh to the E of M, on the buildings in progress at Kimbolton. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 320) Stevenage
E. Howe to the E of M, on the preparations of Hanover for the forthcoming campaign. Hanover

J. Addison to [the E of M], giving some small items of news, including the arrest of the Duke of Hamilton. The French squadron was supposed to have "got into some of the ports of Norway." (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 328)
Colonel Broune de Camus to the E of M, recommending to his favour an Irish gentleman named Hurly, who wished to serve as captain of cavalry in the British army in Spain. (In French) Pavia

A. Stanyan to the E of M, on difficulties arising out of the neglect of the King of Prussia to pay the Swiss troops in Neufchâtel, etc. (The principal part is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 518) Berne [Bern]

J. Addison to the E of M, giving various small items of news. Mr. Stanhope was appointed Envoy Extraordinary to the King of Spain, and Major-General commanding the British forces in Catalonia. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 327)
J. Addison to the E of M on proceedings in Parliament. Cockpit

A. Stanyan to the E of M, to the effect that an agreement would probably be made for the neutrality of Neufchâtel. (Printed, with the exception of a postscript dated April 1, on the subject of the Dunkirk Squadron, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 521) Bern
J. Addison to the E of M on proceedings in Parliament. Cockpit
Thomas Pritchard to the E of M, on domestic matters. London.
The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, informing him of the Queen's resentment when she learned that an affront had been put upon him at Venice. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 524) Whitehall
A. Stanyan to the E of M, informing him that a new project for the neutrality of Neufchâtel would in all probability be ratified. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 523) Bern

J, Addison to the E of M, touching briefly on various matters of gossip... The Government was calling on suspected persons in Scotland, including the Duke of Atholl, to make their appearance. The Venetian Ambassador had been forbidden the Court. Several merchants thought a fitting reparation for the affront put upon the Earl at Venice would be free importation of English cloth there... Cockpit

J. Addison to the E of M, to the effect that the Venetian Ambassador had received "with great uneasiness and something like resentment" the message forbidding him the Court until the Earl had received reparation for the insult at Venice. Parliament was prorogued for a fortnight, and would probably be suddenly dissolved. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 343) Cockpit
The Duchess of Marlborough to the E of M, on musical matters. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 337) St. James
J. Chetwynd to the E of M, mentioning a report which had reached him of a defeat of a French fleet by Sir George Byng. He had no news of importance to communicate. Turin

A. Stanyan to the E of M, announcing that the French King's ratification of the neutrality of Neufchâtel was expected, and suggesting that satisfaction should be demended of the Pope for assistance rendered to the Pretender. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 524) Bern

J. Addison to [the E of M], announcing the arrival in London and committal to the Tower of Lord Griffin, Lord Middleton's two sons and other persons arrested as accomplices in the late attempt of the Pretender. "The people were with much ado restrained from outraging them as they passed the streets." Fifty more state prisoners of distinction were expected. Mr. Smith was made Chancellor of the Exchequer. The factory at Borneo had been "ruined by the natives." He concludes: "It is said that the G. Duke furnished the Pope with the money that he gave the P.P. of Wales. If so, his Minister here will quickly hear of it." (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 348) Whitehall

Lord Halifax to [the E of M]. He would always espouse Lord Manchester's interest though "sensible there were those who did desire" they "should not be well together." Everything would be done to obtain satisfaction for the insult to Lord Manchester at Venice. Lord Sunderland had "talked very roundly" to the Venetian Ambassador who had sent a Memorial in justification. Nothing short of a "public satisfaction" would be accepted. (Printed, in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 349)
Copy of a letter (without signature) apparently to the E of M, on behalf of the Abbate Paolo Franceschini. (In Italian) Venice

A. Stanyan to the E of M, expressing fears that the affairs of Toggenburg would give even more trouble than those of Neufchâtel (now believed to be settled), and explaining the religious and other difficulties of the case. (The principal part is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 525) Bern

The Duke of Würtemberg to the E of M, asking for authentic information respecting the issue of the French expedition to Scotland, concerning which there were contradictory reports. He hoped it was true that the "Chevallier Bings" [Byng] had obtained a considerable advantage. He had orders to proceed to H.R.H. at Turin, and thence to Susa to take command of a corps there. (In French) Mirandola
E. Howe to the E of M, announcing the arrival of the Duke of Marlborough and Prince Eugene at Hanover. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 526) Hanover
The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of a Memorial from the Venetian Ambassador, with the answer to it. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 529) Whitehall

General Cadogan to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of a circular which showed the progress of preparations for the campaign. The Duke of Marlborough was expected at Brussels, and the Duke of Vendôme at St. Amand. Regular accounts of the movements in the fields would be sent to the Earl by Mr. Cardonnel. Brussels

The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, informing him that the Queen desired he should have the fullest reparation for the affront put upon him at Venice, and leave that place if he failed to obtain satisfaction. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 527) Whitehall

J. Chetwynd to the E of M, giving an account of the various preparations made, and being made, for sending succours into Spain. Mr. Stanhope was expected. The Venetian Ambassador, passing through Turin, had failed to see H.R.H., who wished to have as little as possible to do with the Republic. Mr. Chetwynd asked for the Earl's interest with the Ministers. (pp. 6) Turin

A. Stanyan to the E of M, It was not known that the ratifications of the Treaty of Neutrality for Neufchâtel had yet been exchanged. The differences respecting Toggenburg would probably be satisfactorily adjusted, so that the inhabitants could be secured in the free enjoyment of their religion and liberties. It was to be hoped that the Earl would, before leaving Venice, obtain satisfaction for the affront offered him "in visiting his gondola and what is more, plundering it." The Earl would naturally be "little obliged to Mr. Brown that drew him into the difficulty." Bern

J. Chetwynd to the E of M. Mr. Stanhope had arrived, but was "almost as much in the dark" as Chetwynd himself about the expected reinforcement of 5,000 Imperial troops for Spain. He had written very pressingly on the subject both to the Duke of Marlborough and to Lord Sunderland. The delays of the Imperialists were causing uneasiness. "Mr. Palmes" would pass through Venice on his way to Turin. Perhaps, the Earl could ascertain Mr. Chetwynd's "destiny" from him. Turin
General Palmes to the E of M, to the effect that he hoped to conclude his negotiation at Vienna, and proceed to Italy in a few days. Vienna

The E of M to Prince Hercolani, informing him that he was about to start for Vicenza, an the following day, on his return home and that a complete rupture with Venice was imminent. The Duke of Marlborough and Prince Eugene were both at Hanover, and the Duke would not return to England but join the army at once. (Draft. In French) Venice

S. Edwin to the E of M. Correspondence was difficult, as letters were commonly opened, if not intercepted on the way. The Duke of Hamilton had been bailed, and would, in all probability, be "one of the sixteen peers for Scotland." Sir James Montagu was not yet made Attorney-General. The Whigs were stronger in Parliament by 44 votes since the last election, and the Tories and Jacobites much dejected... Exchequer

J. Vanbrugh to the E of M, chiefly on operatic affairs, but with the following postscript: "My Lady Marlborough goes now very often to Court, and is in perfect good humour. I hope all will keep right." (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 354) London
H. Boyle to the E of M, acknowledging the Earl's congratulations offered to him upon his appointment as Secretary. London
A. Stanyan to the E of M, touching briefly on various matters. (Printed, in part, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 352) Bern

Philippo Hercolani to [the E of M]. He expected to be at Mantua on the 21st, and to go on thence to Milan. He thanked the Earl for procuring him the protection of the Queen, and an employment in which he might be useful to the common cause. He hoped to receive letters from the Earl at Milan, and would then endeavour to conclude a business which should awake in the Court of Vienna sentiments consistent with the Imperial dignity. He had never been guilty of any base action in his life, and would not enter upon one now that he had the honour to serve His Imperial Majesty. (In Italian) Crocetta
Valeriano Pellegrini to the E of M, announcing that he was about to set out for Düsseldorf in the following week. (In Italian) Verona

The E of M to the Duke of Marlborough, expressing the belief that the Duke would be the deliverer of this country, and that reparation would be made for the affront offered to himself at Venice. (Copy) Venice
James Stanhope to the E of M, on the prospect of the campaigns in Flanders and Catalonia. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 533) Savona

S. Edwin to the E of M. "The Title of Dover" was not to be given to "Mr. Massam," but to the Duke of Queensborough. The elections had been favourable to the Whigs. There would be another attempt to make Lord Somers and Sir James Montague [Montagu] President of the Council and Attorney- General. A sea expedition with ten regiments from England and Ireland, and the great naval preparation of the Dutch were much talked of. Exchequer
A. Stanyan to the E of M, announcing the ratification of the Treaty for the Neutrality of Neufchâtel. (Printed, almost in full, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 533) Bern
Hurly, an Irishman, to the E of M, asking the latter to intercede for him with the Vice-Roy of Naples, and mentioning a recommendation from Col. Broune. (In French) Naples

General Palmes to the E of M, on the affairs of the Elector Palatine and the Duke of Savoy, and on the concentration of 40,000 men at Coblentz under Prince Eugene. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 534) Vienna

Thomas Pritchard to the E of M, mentioning the indisposition of the Venetian Ambassador, and consquent difficulty of delivering a box to him and obtaining a receipt. There were great complaints of the scarcity of money in England. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 358) London

J. Chetwynd to the E of Mon the formation of camps at Bussolino and Ivrea, the seizure of Comaccio, and the probable reluctance of other powers to let the Emperor have so good a port in the Adriatic. The Queen of Spain was in Milan. There had been no news of the fleet. Turin

J. Quinton to the E of M, chiefly on family matters. He had waited on the Duchess of Marlborough "with the patterns" which "pleased her extremely," and she would "give his Lordship more trouble about them." (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 359) London
The Duke of Marlborough to the E of M, expressing willingness to join with Lord Sunderland in any thing the Earl could desire. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 535) Camp at Torbanck

Lady Elizabeth Montague [Montagu] to her brother the E of M, on his probable return to England, and on various matters of gossip, e.g., the marriages of friends, etc. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 365)
Henry Newton to the E of M, announcing the capture of a number of French vessels laden with ammunition, etc, by Sir John Lake. Florence

J. Chetwynd to the E of M, to the effect that he had been engaged in fitting out transports which would be ready on the 5th or 6th of the following month, and have all the troops embarked on them within ten days afterwards. Vado

Paolo Abbate Franceschini to the E of M, thanking him for his patronage and protection. He had met the Secretary of the Imperial Ambassador, from whom he had learned that he might expect a letter from the Duca Moles. (In Italian) Milan
Alexandre de Bonneval to the E of M, pointing out the advantages of the site of Commacchio for commercial purposes and as a harbour for ships of war. (In French) Commacchio

Undirected letter of the Duca Moles to the effect that he had presented the Memorial which had been forwarded by the Envoy Stanhope, to "His Majesty" [Charles III of Spain?], who regarded it favourably, and was disposed to grant a pension. (Copy. In Italian. See 31) Barcelona

Paolo Abbate Franceschini to the E of M, enclosing a copy of a letter from the Duca Moles, which had been sent to the Abbate by the Imperial Ambassador at Venice, and again thanking the Earl for his protection and recommendation. (In Italian. See 30. Endorsed, "Ab. Franceschini, and one from the D. of Moles.")

A. Stanyan to the E of M, announcing that the Pope had asked the Catholic Cantons for assistance against the Emperor to defend the Holy See, as the Imperial Troops had invaded the Ferrarese, and that the French Ambassador, M. Puisieulx, was to be succeeded by the Comte de Gerzé. He mentions enclosure of a copy of the Nuncio's Memorial to the Cantons. Bern

The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, acknowledging the receipt of copies of a Memorial of Lord Manchester, and of the Senate's answer to it, and assuring him of the Queen's complete approval of all his proceedings. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 540) Whitehall

Sir John Norris to the E of M, giving a variety of details of the military position and prospects in Spain, and of the embarcation of troops at Vado. (pp.6) On board the Ranelaugh, with the fleet, at Vado

G. Germain to the E of M, apologising for his delay in writing, caused by the supposition that the Earl was about to return at once from Venice. He had had the Lord Treasurer, Lord Sunderland, Mr. Boyle, and "le bonne homme Mons. de Spanheim" to dine with him, and they had drunk the Earl's health. (In French) London

Sir P. Medows to the E of M, congratulating the Earl upon his success at Venice, giving some particulars respecting Prince Eugene and the Duke of Savoy's affairs, and mentioning in a postscript the threatening attitude of "the Swede." (pp. 6) Vienna

A. Stanyan to the E of M, announcing that the religious difficulty in Toggenberg was accommodated, that the Catholic Cantons would probably send 3,000 men to the assistance of the Pope, and that the Duke of Savoy would put in the field an army of 36,000 foot and 8,000 horse. (Printed, in part only, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 540) Bern

Sir P. Medows to the E of M, on the introduction of the Elector of Hanover into the Electoral College, and on various matters relating to Imperial politics. (The greater part is printed under date July 7, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 542) Vienna
The E of M to the Duchess of Marlborough, on the subject of velvets and damasks. (Draft) Venice
Paolo Franceschini to [the E of M?], announcing that he [had] secured a passage to Vado, and been promised an introduction to Admiral Leake. (In Italian) Genoa
Thomas Kirke to the E of M, to the effect that a passage to Barcelona had been secured for the Abbate Franceschini on board H.M.S. Defiance. Genoa
The Duca du Moles to the E of M, expressing pleasure at having been able to use his influence to procure a pension for the Abbate Franceschini from the King of Spain. (In Italian) Barcelona
C. Cole to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of various letters, and touching on various rumours and matters of gossip. (Printed, in part, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 544) Venice
The Duke of Marlborough to the E of M, giving some particulars of the battle of Oudenarde. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 544) Camp at Wervick
General Palmes to the E of M, conveying news of the French defeat at Oudenarde. Vienna
M. Runkel to a person addressed as "Monsieur" [Mr. Stanyan], giving particulars of the battle of Oudenarde. (In French. Copy. See 48 and 49) Schaffhausen

J. Chetwynd to the E of M, giving some particulars of the embarcation at Vado, and mentioning the success of Mr. [General] Palmes in securing the investiture of Montferrat for the Duke of Savoy. (Printed in part in Cole's Memoirs, p. 545) Genoa
M. Runkel's paper, giving fuller details of the news conveyed in his letter of the 20th July. (In French. 7 pages. Copy.) Schaffhausen
A. Stanyan to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of copies of letters from the Dutch Minister at Schaffhausen, in the Victory at Oudenarde. (See 46 and 48) Bern

J. Addison to the E of M, mentioning the arrest of the Muscovite Ambassador by bailiffs, expressing strong hopes of the success of the combined operations against France, congratulating the Earl on the approbation given to his conduct at Venice, etc. (Printed in part in Cole's Memoirs, 546) Cockpit

The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, conveying the Queen's approval of Lord Manchester's prudent conduct at Venice, and mentioning the enclosure of a letter of recall to be used as Lord Manchester might see fit. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 545) Whitehall

Sir P. Medows to the E of M, expressing his belief that it would be difficult to make the Court of Vienna "go a different pace from what it thinks fittest to go." There was, however, a King whose "Gothic politics" made their councils "a little uneasy and uncertain." It was to be hoped the Duke [of Marlborough] would "set us up in the world again." Vienna
The Duchess of Marlborough to [the E of M], on the subject of velvets and damasks. Windsor Castle

Sir John Norris to the E of M, conveying the information that he had landed the troops at Barcelona, and giving various particulars relating to the probable course of the campaign in the Peninsula. (5 pages. A part is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 545) Ranelaugh, with the fleet

The E of M to the Lord Treasurer, asking to be named Plenipotentiary, in the event of a peace with France. His dispute at Venice had been at last adjusted. (Draft. Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 373) Venice

J. Vanbrugh to the E of M, explaining how he had lost money by the opera, giving details of the buildings at Blenheim, etc., and mentioning that the Duchess of Marlborough was "mighty well at Court, but the Q.'s fondness of t'other lady was not to be expressed." (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 377) London
A. Stanyan to the E of M, giving further particulars relating to the battle of Oudenarde and its results. Bern
E. Lewis to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of a lampoon said to have been made by Mr. M...r, and congratulating him upon his approaching return to England. Whitehall

The Duchess of Marlborough to the E of M, thanking him very warmly for the trouble he had already taken, and giving very full details of the velvets, damasks, etc, which she wished to have sent to her. (Printed in Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 387) Windsor Castle

The E of M to the Duke of Marlborough, congratulating him upon the victory of Oudenarde, making some comments upon the general military situation, and expressing his anxiety to leave Venice. (Draft) Venice
A paper unsigned and unaddressed, giving an account of the disembarcation of troops at Barcelona, and of the military situation in Spain. (In French) Barcelona
A. Stanyan to the E of M, mentioning enclosure of a paper in French, and giving some details of the disposition of forces in Flanders and on the Rhine. Bern

The E of M to Lord Halifax, complaining of an attack made upon his gondola at Venice, and explaining the necessity of having some public satisfaction. (Draft. the particulars are given at greater length in the Earl's letters to Sunderland, dated May 30, and April 6, and printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 519 and p. 521) Venice
The Duchess of Marlborough to the E of M "I have received the honour of Your Lordship's letter...and I am sure ...your papers will be of great use..." Windsor Castle

Paolo Abbate Franceschini to the E of M, announcing that he had seen the British Envoy, General Stanhope, and the Duca Moles, and that his promised pension was to issue out of lands in Italy, from which he would probably receive nothing for years. He askes for a further recommendation from the Earl, and mentions the arrival of the fleet and troops at Barcelona. (In Italian.) Barcelona
W. Chetwynd to the E of M, announcing that he concluded he would be Resident at Genoa, and mentions the arrival of the fleet and troops at Barcelona. (In Italian) Barcelona
E. Howe to the E of M, describing the position of the forces in the Rhine. Muhlberg
J. Chetwynd to the E of M, describing the difficulties of the mountain passes, and expressing hopes of a successful campaign. Chaumont

Unsigned letter to the E of M on the state of the Court, a quarrel between the Duchess of Marlborough and the Lord Chamberlain, and the probability that the Earl might obtain the Lord Chamberlain's Post. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 383) London
The Duke of Marlborough to the E of M, expressing hopes that the Campaign would be followed by an honourable and lasting peace. (Printed, Cole's Memoirs, p. 546) Camp at Helchin
J. Vanbrugh to the E of M, on the re-building at Kimbolton, and on operatic affairs. (Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 383) Biggleswade

W. Chetwynd to the E of M, mentioning enclosure from Sir J. Norris on the state of affairs in Spain. The Emperor would be asked to send 4,000 foot out of the forces in Italy, but it was not expected that he would consent. Five men-of-war had touched at Genoa, and just been despatched, Chetwynd had sent with them 50,000 pistoles for Mr. Stanhope. Thr money might "be able to stop many a man's mouth, and raise their spirits," of which there was need. Genoa
Sir John Norris to the E of M, describing the capture of "Callery" [Cagliari]. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 547 "Ranelaugh, near Callery"
A. Stanyan to the E of M, giving particulars of the various military movements as reported to him. Bern
The Duke of Marlborough to the E of M, announcing the commencement of the siege of Lille. (Printed. Cole's Memoirs, p. 547) Camp at Amongies

Sir P. Medows to the E of M, giving an account of the reinforcements to be sent by the Emperor to serve under General Staremberg in Spain, togher with some particulars of the unsatisfactory plight of the Hanoverians and Würtembergers. Vienna
General Palmes to the E of M, describing some of the movements of the Duke of Savoy, who was not expected to march beyond Fenestrelles for some time. Turin

J. Chetwynd to the E of M, informing him that as Fenestrelles had fallen, nothing further would be undertaken by the Duke of Savoy until another year. (Printed, in part, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 547) Camp at Mantoule, near Fenestrelles
The Earl of Sunderland to the E of M, congratulating him upon the satisfactory termination of the affair at Venice. (Printed, nearly in full, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 551) Whitehall
The E of M to the Duchess of Marlborough, on the damasks, velvets, etc. which he had been purchasing for her, etc. (Draft. Printed in "Court and Society from Elizabeth to Anne," ii, 389) Venice

The E of M to the Duke of Marlborough, announcing that he was about to have his audience of leave on the following day. The British fleet had gone to Port Mahon. Nothing untoward was to be apprehended except only that the promised reinforcements would not be sent by the Emperor from Naples to Spain by reason of the dispute with the Pope. The Republic of Venice would not "concern themselves till they saw a sure game." Venice

The E of M to the Earl of Sunderland, mentioning enclosure of the speech made at his last audience of the Doge. The fleet had sailed for Minorca. (Draft. Printed, with some variations, in Cole's Memoirs, p. 549) Venice
Translation of the answer made to the last speech of the E of M by the Senate. (A translation, substantially the same, but differently worded, is printed in Cole's Memoirs, p. 552) Venice

The E of M to the Lord Treasurer, to the effect that he was about to return home by way of Hanover and Holland, and that the dispute between the Emperor and the Pope appeared to be gainig strength. (Draft) Venice

The E of M to the Earl of Sunderland, alleging that the attack on his boat had been made at the instigation of the Inquisitor Ruzzini, and asking for a credential letter to be presented by Mr. Cole to the College. (Draft. Printed with some variations in Cole's Memoirs, p. 551) Venice
The Principe di Chiusano to the E of M, wishing the Earl a prosperous journey to London, and requesting to have his own respects conveyed to the Duke of Marlborough in Flanders. (In Italian) Naples

The Marquis de Prié to the E of M. The squadron for the transport of troops from Naples to Barcelona had arrived at Leghorn on the 29th of the previous month. Cardinal Grimani, the Viceroy of Naples, however, was of opinion that it might be with advantage detained in Italian waters, as there did not appear to be a necessity for large reinforcements in Spain. Great vigilance would be required to thwart the schemes of the French in favour of an Italian league with the Pope. Marshal de Tessé had not, however, as yet been very successful, and it did not seem probable that he would have better fortune at Venice than elsewhere. De Prié himself had been sent to Rome by the Emperor, with the object of inducing the Pope to disarm. (In French) Rome
R. Powys to the E of M, on money matters. Whitehall
A Statement of accounts. Venice

The E of M to the Earl of Sunderland, describing his journey homewards. He would probably travel with the Duke of Marlborough after leaving the Hague, and asked for a yacht for his voyage to England. He thanked Lord Sunderland for having "settled Mr. Cole at Venice." (Draft) Hanover
The E of M to the Earl of Sunderland, mentioning a report that Brussels was invested by the Elector of Bavaria. (Draft) The Hague

The E of M to Mr. Secretary Boyle, to the effect that there was great joy in Holland at the crossing of the Scheldt by the Duke of Marlborough, and the relief of Brussels. It is now plain wherever the Duke marches the enemy will retire as fast as they can." The Dutch were disposed to continue the war and augment their forces. There had been an exchange of courtesies between the Earl and the Muscovite Ambassador. (Draft) The Hague

The Duke of Marlborough to the E of M, expressing regret that he would not be able to meet the Earl in Holland, and mentioning the affair of the Scheldt, and the good news that the Elector [of Bavaria] had been "obliged to raise the siege of Brussels very shamefully" Alost
R. Powys to the E of M, enclosing statements of accounts, etc, and statements of the allowances to the Earl of Ranelaugh, as paymaster of the forces, and to Mr. Howe.
Speech made in the College at Venice by Mr. Cole, Her Majesty's Secretary there, on presentation of Credentials. (In Italian) Venice
The E of M to the Duchess of Marlborough, on the subject of velvets and damasks. (Draft)
Reply to the answer made by the Court of Vienna to the Memorial of the E of M on the subject of the claims of the Duke of Savoy. (Copy, pp. 6. In French)

An unsigned and undated statement concerning politics and military movements on the Continent. The "army of Guebrian" was "in great straits." The King of France was not expected to live, though his health was somewhat improved by "using the waters of Forges." The Jesuits were growing "mighty insolent." ...Then follow some further small details of foreign politics and military movements, along which occurs the following passage: "It is certain there have been fiery and bloody apparitions of rods and a sword seen again over the city of Leipzig which always have portended some great action or other." There had been a happy conclusion of the great meeting at the Hague. The Prince of Orange would be "kept under," and the common good of the Netherlands "advanced and secured. The Parliament of England had cause to rejoice at this good news." (pp. 7) Paris and Amsterdam
Treaty of Neutrality of the Duchy and County of Burgundy, between Louis XIII of France, and Phillip III of Spain. (In French. Copy. pp. 23) Paris
Captain General Domenico Moconigo to Captain General da Mar on commercial regulations affecting the islands of Zante and Cephalonia. (In Italian) "Romania"
First speech of Lord Fauconberge to the Duke and Senate of Venice. (Copy) Venice

Extracts (apparently) from the correspondence of Sir Henry Wotton (Ambassador at Venice in 1609) and Sir Dudley Carleton (Ambassador at Venice in 1610), touching the honours due to Ambassadors upon their reception at Venice. Venice
Speech of the English resident upon reception and presentation of Credentials at Venice. (Copy) Venice
Answer of the Senate to the speech of Lord Fauconberge, English Ambassador at Venice, when taking leave. (Copy) Venice
Abstract of negotiations at Venice from 1560 to 1639, giving the names of the English Residents and Ambassadors. (24 pages)
Statement of the case of Mr. Hayles, English Consul at Venice in respect of "consolage" dues of that port.
Instructions to Sir Thomas Higgons, Envoy Extraordinary to the Republic of Venice. (Copy) Whitehall

Memorial of Marie Cardin, widow of Elie Genays (laundress in ordinary of the Queen Dowager of England) to the King of France. Her goods had been seized as if she had been one of the fugitives from France, who were affected by the Revocation of the Edict of Nantes. She had, however, a brevet de congé (recited) which was dated Oct. 26, 1682, and she prayed relief. The memorial was, according to the endorsement, to be placed in the hands of the English Ambassador. (In French)

Hugh Broughton to the Duke of Shrewsbury, on the circumstances of his reception as English consul at Venice. The letter concludes with an anecdote of the Conte della Torre, who died of vexation at the manner in which he was treated by the College. (Three very large closely- written pages) Venice
List of Secretaries and Under Secretaries of State, and of the Household apparently of James II when living at St. Germains.
J. Oldfield to the E of M, to introduce a Prince of the House of Brunswick- Wolfuenbüttel. (In French) Wolfenbüttel

Certificate of delivery of a plate to the E of M, from the Jewel House, upon the occasion of his embassies in 1697 and 1699. The total amounts to 1,779 oz. of gilt valued at 889 l. 10s., and 6,337 oz. of white, valued at 2,165 l. 2s. 10d.

The Lord Keeper (Sir Nathan Wright) to the Lord Great Chamberlain, in reference to a gallery to be erected by Sir Christopher Wren "over the lobby door cross to the House," for which the Lord Chamberlain was desired to issue his warrant. (Copy)
C. Cole to the Duke and Senate of Venice, asking for a passport for the house furniture of the E of M to be conveyed overland to England. (In Italian) Venice
"Jacomo" Peiger to James d'Ayrol, (Secretary to the British Embassy at the Hague), on the transmission of the effects belonging to the E of M. (In Italian) Nuremburg
R. Powys to the E of M, on money matters.

Lord Townshend, by the King's direction, to the E of M (Lord Lieutenant of the county of Huntingdon), recommending the due and punctual execution of an Order in Council to enforce the laws concerning Papists, Non-jurors, and other disaffected persons. Whitehall

Lord Townshend to the E of M (Lord Lieutenant of the County of Huntingdon), directing him to "take care of regulating the militia" of his county, and especially to give notice to those who had to provide horses that they were to prepare for marching whenever his Majesty's service should require it. Whitehall

The E of M to the Deputy-Lieutenants of the county of Huntingdon, instructing them to "put the militia in good order, especially the horse." In order to save expense to the county, cloth coats "all of a colour" might be substituted for buff coats and "would be handsomer and more useful." He did not doubt that proper care would be taken for seizing the arms and horses and apprehending the persons of all who might be suspected. Kimbolton
Lord Mandeville to the Duke of Manchester, describing the antiquities, etc. in the neighborhood of Naples. Naples
Lord Mandeville to the Duke of Manchester, asking for the Duke's interest in favour of Mr. Skinner. Lucca
Lord Manchester to the Duke of Manchester, asking for the Duke's interest in favour of Mr. Skinner. Lucca

Princess Panfili to the Duke of Manchester, giving an account of Lord Mandeville's recovery from a serious illness, of his departure from Rome, and of the care bestowed upon him by Mr. Beverley. (In French) Rome
Princess Panfili to the Duke of Manchester, asking that Mr. Beverley might be appointed Mr. Davenant's successor as English "Envoy" at Genoa. (In French) Genoa

Rev. Peter Boundy (The Duke's chaplain) to the Duke of Manchester, giving the state of the poll at a recent election [for Bedfordshire], when Mr. Bing [Byng] and "Sir Rowland" [Alston] were successful, and gave "such a mortifying blow to that furious party" that he never expected "to see them lift up their heads any more." Dean
Lord Warwick to the Duke of Manchester, mentioning some appointments and rumours. London
Estimate of the cost of some damask and mohair.
"Account of what was bought at Venice for her Grace the Duchess of Marlborough." (In the Handwriting of the E of M.)
